THE PCRE BIT LIBRARY Starting with release
 
THE PCRE BIT LIBRARY Starting with it is possible to compile a PCRE library that supports bit character strings
 
THE PCRE BIT LIBRARY Starting with it is possible to compile a PCRE library that supports bit character including UTF as well as or instead of the original bit library The majority of the work to make this possible was done by Zoltan Herczeg The two libraries contain identical sets of functions
 
THE PCRE BIT LIBRARY Starting with it is possible to compile a PCRE library that supports bit character including UTF as well as or instead of the original bit library The majority of the work to make this possible was done by Zoltan Herczeg The two libraries contain identical sets of used in exactly the same way Only the names of the functions and the data types of their argu ments and results are different To avoid over complication and reduce the documentation maintenance load
 
THE PCRE BIT LIBRARY Starting with it is possible to compile a PCRE library that supports bit character including UTF as well as or instead of the original bit library The majority of the work to make this possible was done by Zoltan Herczeg The two libraries contain identical sets of used in exactly the same way Only the names of the functions and the data types of their argu ments and results are different To avoid over complication and reduce the documentation maintenance most of the PCRE documentation describes the bit library
 
THE PCRE BIT LIBRARY Starting with it is possible to compile a PCRE library that supports bit character including UTF as well as or instead of the original bit library The majority of the work to make this possible was done by Zoltan Herczeg The two libraries contain identical sets of used in exactly the same way Only the names of the functions and the data types of their argu ments and results are different To avoid over complication and reduce the documentation maintenance most of the PCRE documentation describes the bit with only occasional references to the bit library This page describes what is different when you use the bit library WARNING
 
THE PCRE BIT LIBRARY Starting with it is possible to compile a PCRE library that supports bit character including UTF as well as or instead of the original bit library The majority of the work to make this possible was done by Zoltan Herczeg The two libraries contain identical sets of used in exactly the same way Only the names of the functions and the data types of their argu ments and results are different To avoid over complication and reduce the documentation maintenance most of the PCRE documentation describes the bit with only occasional references to the bit library This page describes what is different when you use the bit library but you must take care when processing any particular pattern to use func tions from just one library For example
 
THE PCRE BIT LIBRARY Starting with it is possible to compile a PCRE library that supports bit character including UTF as well as or instead of the original bit library The majority of the work to make this possible was done by Zoltan Herczeg The two libraries contain identical sets of used in exactly the same way Only the names of the functions and the data types of their argu ments and results are different To avoid over complication and reduce the documentation maintenance most of the PCRE documentation describes the bit with only occasional references to the bit library This page describes what is different when you use the bit library but you must take care when processing any particular pattern to use func tions from just one library For if you want to study a pat tern that was compiled with you must do so with not and you must free the study data with pcre h It contains prototypes for all the functions in all libraries
 
THE PCRE BIT LIBRARY Starting with it is possible to compile a PCRE library that supports bit character including UTF as well as or instead of the original bit library The majority of the work to make this possible was done by Zoltan Herczeg The two libraries contain identical sets of used in exactly the same way Only the names of the functions and the data types of their argu ments and results are different To avoid over complication and reduce the documentation maintenance most of the PCRE documentation describes the bit with only occasional references to the bit library This page describes what is different when you use the bit library but you must take care when processing any particular pattern to use func tions from just one library For if you want to study a pat tern that was compiled with you must do so with not and you must free the study data with pcre h It contains prototypes for all the functions in all as well as definitions of flags
 
THE PCRE BIT LIBRARY Starting with it is possible to compile a PCRE library that supports bit character including UTF as well as or instead of the original bit library The majority of the work to make this possible was done by Zoltan Herczeg The two libraries contain identical sets of used in exactly the same way Only the names of the functions and the data types of their argu ments and results are different To avoid over complication and reduce the documentation maintenance most of the PCRE documentation describes the bit with only occasional references to the bit library This page describes what is different when you use the bit library but you must take care when processing any particular pattern to use func tions from just one library For if you want to study a pat tern that was compiled with you must do so with not and you must free the study data with pcre h It contains prototypes for all the functions in all as well as definitions of struc tures
 
THE PCRE BIT LIBRARY Starting with it is possible to compile a PCRE library that supports bit character including UTF as well as or instead of the original bit library The majority of the work to make this possible was done by Zoltan Herczeg The two libraries contain identical sets of used in exactly the same way Only the names of the functions and the data types of their argu ments and results are different To avoid over complication and reduce the documentation maintenance most of the PCRE documentation describes the bit with only occasional references to the bit library This page describes what is different when you use the bit library but you must take care when processing any particular pattern to use func tions from just one library For if you want to study a pat tern that was compiled with you must do so with not and you must free the study data with pcre h It contains prototypes for all the functions in all as well as definitions of struc error codes
 
THE PCRE BIT LIBRARY Starting with it is possible to compile a PCRE library that supports bit character including UTF as well as or instead of the original bit library The majority of the work to make this possible was done by Zoltan Herczeg The two libraries contain identical sets of used in exactly the same way Only the names of the functions and the data types of their argu ments and results are different To avoid over complication and reduce the documentation maintenance most of the PCRE documentation describes the bit with only occasional references to the bit library This page describes what is different when you use the bit library but you must take care when processing any particular pattern to use func tions from just one library For if you want to study a pat tern that was compiled with you must do so with not and you must free the study data with pcre h It contains prototypes for all the functions in all as well as definitions of struc error etc THE LIBRARY NAME In Unix like systems
 
THE PCRE BIT LIBRARY Starting with it is possible to compile a PCRE library that supports bit character including UTF as well as or instead of the original bit library The majority of the work to make this possible was done by Zoltan Herczeg The two libraries contain identical sets of used in exactly the same way Only the names of the functions and the data types of their argu ments and results are different To avoid over complication and reduce the documentation maintenance most of the PCRE documentation describes the bit with only occasional references to the bit library This page describes what is different when you use the bit library but you must take care when processing any particular pattern to use func tions from just one library For if you want to study a pat tern that was compiled with you must do so with not and you must free the study data with pcre h It contains prototypes for all the functions in all as well as definitions of struc error etc THE LIBRARY NAME In Unix like the bit library is called and can normally be accesss by adding lpcre16 to the command for linking an application that uses PCRE STRING TYPES In the bit strings are passed to PCRE library functions as vectors of bytes with the C type char *In the bit strings are passed as vectors of unsigned bit quantities The macro PCRE_UCHAR16 specifies an appropriate data type
 
THE PCRE BIT LIBRARY Starting with it is possible to compile a PCRE library that supports bit character including UTF as well as or instead of the original bit library The majority of the work to make this possible was done by Zoltan Herczeg The two libraries contain identical sets of used in exactly the same way Only the names of the functions and the data types of their argu ments and results are different To avoid over complication and reduce the documentation maintenance most of the PCRE documentation describes the bit with only occasional references to the bit library This page describes what is different when you use the bit library but you must take care when processing any particular pattern to use func tions from just one library For if you want to study a pat tern that was compiled with you must do so with not and you must free the study data with pcre h It contains prototypes for all the functions in all as well as definitions of struc error etc THE LIBRARY NAME In Unix like the bit library is called and can normally be accesss by adding lpcre16 to the command for linking an application that uses PCRE STRING TYPES In the bit strings are passed to PCRE library functions as vectors of bytes with the C type char *In the bit strings are passed as vectors of unsigned bit quantities The macro PCRE_UCHAR16 specifies an appropriate data and PCRE_SPTR16 is defined as const PCRE_UCHAR16 *In very many short int is a bit data type When PCRE is it defines PCRE_UCHAR16 as unsigned short int
 
THE PCRE BIT LIBRARY Starting with it is possible to compile a PCRE library that supports bit character including UTF as well as or instead of the original bit library The majority of the work to make this possible was done by Zoltan Herczeg The two libraries contain identical sets of used in exactly the same way Only the names of the functions and the data types of their argu ments and results are different To avoid over complication and reduce the documentation maintenance most of the PCRE documentation describes the bit with only occasional references to the bit library This page describes what is different when you use the bit library but you must take care when processing any particular pattern to use func tions from just one library For if you want to study a pat tern that was compiled with you must do so with not and you must free the study data with pcre h It contains prototypes for all the functions in all as well as definitions of struc error etc THE LIBRARY NAME In Unix like the bit library is called and can normally be accesss by adding lpcre16 to the command for linking an application that uses PCRE STRING TYPES In the bit strings are passed to PCRE library functions as vectors of bytes with the C type char *In the bit strings are passed as vectors of unsigned bit quantities The macro PCRE_UCHAR16 specifies an appropriate data and PCRE_SPTR16 is defined as const PCRE_UCHAR16 *In very many short int is a bit data type When PCRE is it defines PCRE_UCHAR16 as unsigned short but checks that it really is a bit data type If it is not
 
THE PCRE BIT LIBRARY Starting with it is possible to compile a PCRE library that supports bit character including UTF as well as or instead of the original bit library The majority of the work to make this possible was done by Zoltan Herczeg The two libraries contain identical sets of used in exactly the same way Only the names of the functions and the data types of their argu ments and results are different To avoid over complication and reduce the documentation maintenance most of the PCRE documentation describes the bit with only occasional references to the bit library This page describes what is different when you use the bit library but you must take care when processing any particular pattern to use func tions from just one library For if you want to study a pat tern that was compiled with you must do so with not and you must free the study data with pcre h It contains prototypes for all the functions in all as well as definitions of struc error etc THE LIBRARY NAME In Unix like the bit library is called and can normally be accesss by adding lpcre16 to the command for linking an application that uses PCRE STRING TYPES In the bit strings are passed to PCRE library functions as vectors of bytes with the C type char *In the bit strings are passed as vectors of unsigned bit quantities The macro PCRE_UCHAR16 specifies an appropriate data and PCRE_SPTR16 is defined as const PCRE_UCHAR16 *In very many short int is a bit data type When PCRE is it defines PCRE_UCHAR16 as unsigned short but checks that it really is a bit data type If it is the build fails with an error message telling the maintainer to modify the definition appropriately STRUCTURE TYPES The types of the opaque structures that are used for compiled bit patterns and JIT stacks are pcre16 and pcre16_jit_stack respectively The type of the user accessible structure that is returned by and the type of the structure that is used for passing data to a callout function is pcre16_callout_block These structures contain the same fields
 
THE PCRE BIT LIBRARY Starting with it is possible to compile a PCRE library that supports bit character including UTF as well as or instead of the original bit library The majority of the work to make this possible was done by Zoltan Herczeg The two libraries contain identical sets of used in exactly the same way Only the names of the functions and the data types of their argu ments and results are different To avoid over complication and reduce the documentation maintenance most of the PCRE documentation describes the bit with only occasional references to the bit library This page describes what is different when you use the bit library but you must take care when processing any particular pattern to use func tions from just one library For if you want to study a pat tern that was compiled with you must do so with not and you must free the study data with pcre h It contains prototypes for all the functions in all as well as definitions of struc error etc THE LIBRARY NAME In Unix like the bit library is called and can normally be accesss by adding lpcre16 to the command for linking an application that uses PCRE STRING TYPES In the bit strings are passed to PCRE library functions as vectors of bytes with the C type char *In the bit strings are passed as vectors of unsigned bit quantities The macro PCRE_UCHAR16 specifies an appropriate data and PCRE_SPTR16 is defined as const PCRE_UCHAR16 *In very many short int is a bit data type When PCRE is it defines PCRE_UCHAR16 as unsigned short but checks that it really is a bit data type If it is the build fails with an error message telling the maintainer to modify the definition appropriately STRUCTURE TYPES The types of the opaque structures that are used for compiled bit patterns and JIT stacks are pcre16 and pcre16_jit_stack respectively The type of the user accessible structure that is returned by and the type of the structure that is used for passing data to a callout function is pcre16_callout_block These structures contain the same with the same names
 
THE PCRE BIT LIBRARY Starting with it is possible to compile a PCRE library that supports bit character including UTF as well as or instead of the original bit library The majority of the work to make this possible was done by Zoltan Herczeg The two libraries contain identical sets of used in exactly the same way Only the names of the functions and the data types of their argu ments and results are different To avoid over complication and reduce the documentation maintenance most of the PCRE documentation describes the bit with only occasional references to the bit library This page describes what is different when you use the bit library but you must take care when processing any particular pattern to use func tions from just one library For if you want to study a pat tern that was compiled with you must do so with not and you must free the study data with pcre h It contains prototypes for all the functions in all as well as definitions of struc error etc THE LIBRARY NAME In Unix like the bit library is called and can normally be accesss by adding lpcre16 to the command for linking an application that uses PCRE STRING TYPES In the bit strings are passed to PCRE library functions as vectors of bytes with the C type char *In the bit strings are passed as vectors of unsigned bit quantities The macro PCRE_UCHAR16 specifies an appropriate data and PCRE_SPTR16 is defined as const PCRE_UCHAR16 *In very many short int is a bit data type When PCRE is it defines PCRE_UCHAR16 as unsigned short but checks that it really is a bit data type If it is the build fails with an error message telling the maintainer to modify the definition appropriately STRUCTURE TYPES The types of the opaque structures that are used for compiled bit patterns and JIT stacks are pcre16 and pcre16_jit_stack respectively The type of the user accessible structure that is returned by and the type of the structure that is used for passing data to a callout function is pcre16_callout_block These structures contain the same with the same as their bit counterparts The only difference is that pointers to character strings are bit instead of bit types BIT FUNCTIONS For every function in the bit library there is a corresponding func tion in the bit library with a name that starts with pcre16_ instead of pcre_ The prototypes are listed above In addition
 
a negative value specifies a zero terminated string If byte_order is it is assumed that the string starts off in host byte order This may be changed by byte order a non zero value of the integer to which it points means that the input starts off in host byte order
 
a negative value specifies a zero terminated string If byte_order is it is assumed that the string starts off in host byte order This may be changed by byte order a non zero value of the integer to which it points means that the input starts off in host byte otherwise the opposite order is assumed Again
 
a negative value specifies a zero terminated string If byte_order is it is assumed that the string starts off in host byte order This may be changed by byte order a non zero value of the integer to which it points means that the input starts off in host byte otherwise the opposite order is assumed BOMs in the string can change this The final byte order is passed back at the end of processing If keep_boms is not zero
 
a negative value specifies a zero terminated string If byte_order is it is assumed that the string starts off in host byte order This may be changed by byte order a non zero value of the integer to which it points means that the input starts off in host byte otherwise the opposite order is assumed BOMs in the string can change this The final byte order is passed back at the end of processing If keep_boms is not byte order mark including the zero terminator if the string was zero terminated SUBJECT STRING OFFSETS The lengths and starting offsets of subject strings must be specified in bit data units
 
a negative value specifies a zero terminated string If byte_order is it is assumed that the string starts off in host byte order This may be changed by byte order a non zero value of the integer to which it points means that the input starts off in host byte otherwise the opposite order is assumed BOMs in the string can change this The final byte order is passed back at the end of processing If keep_boms is not byte order mark including the zero terminator if the string was zero terminated SUBJECT STRING OFFSETS The lengths and starting offsets of subject strings must be specified in bit data and the offsets within subject strings that are returned by the matching functions are in also bit units rather than bytes NAMED SUBPATTERNS The name to number translation table that is maintained for named sub patterns uses bit characters The PCRE_UTF16 and PCRE_NO_UTF16_CHECK
 
a negative value specifies a zero terminated string If byte_order is it is assumed that the string starts off in host byte order This may be changed by byte order a non zero value of the integer to which it points means that the input starts off in host byte otherwise the opposite order is assumed BOMs in the string can change this The final byte order is passed back at the end of processing If keep_boms is not byte order mark including the zero terminator if the string was zero terminated SUBJECT STRING OFFSETS The lengths and starting offsets of subject strings must be specified in bit data and the offsets within subject strings that are returned by the matching functions are in also bit units rather than bytes NAMED SUBPATTERNS The name to number translation table that is maintained for named sub patterns uses bit characters The PCRE_UTF16 and which correspond to PCRE_UTF8 and PCRE_NO_UTF8_CHECK in the bit library In fact
 
a negative value specifies a zero terminated string If byte_order is it is assumed that the string starts off in host byte order This may be changed by byte order a non zero value of the integer to which it points means that the input starts off in host byte otherwise the opposite order is assumed BOMs in the string can change this The final byte order is passed back at the end of processing If keep_boms is not byte order mark including the zero terminator if the string was zero terminated SUBJECT STRING OFFSETS The lengths and starting offsets of subject strings must be specified in bit data and the offsets within subject strings that are returned by the matching functions are in also bit units rather than bytes NAMED SUBPATTERNS The name to number translation table that is maintained for named sub patterns uses bit characters The PCRE_UTF16 and which correspond to PCRE_UTF8 and PCRE_NO_UTF8_CHECK in the bit library In these new options define the same bits in the options word There is a discussion about the validity of UTF strings in the pcreunicode page For the otherwise If this option is given to or if the PCRE_CONFIG_UTF8 or PCRE_CONFIG_UTF32 option is given to pcre16_con the result is the PCRE_ERROR_BADOPTION error CHARACTER CODES In bit mode
 
a negative value specifies a zero terminated string If byte_order is it is assumed that the string starts off in host byte order This may be changed by byte order a non zero value of the integer to which it points means that the input starts off in host byte otherwise the opposite order is assumed BOMs in the string can change this The final byte order is passed back at the end of processing If keep_boms is not byte order mark including the zero terminator if the string was zero terminated SUBJECT STRING OFFSETS The lengths and starting offsets of subject strings must be specified in bit data and the offsets within subject strings that are returned by the matching functions are in also bit units rather than bytes NAMED SUBPATTERNS The name to number translation table that is maintained for named sub patterns uses bit characters The PCRE_UTF16 and which correspond to PCRE_UTF8 and PCRE_NO_UTF8_CHECK in the bit library In these new options define the same bits in the options word There is a discussion about the validity of UTF strings in the pcreunicode page For the otherwise If this option is given to or if the PCRE_CONFIG_UTF8 or PCRE_CONFIG_UTF32 option is given to pcre16_con the result is the PCRE_ERROR_BADOPTION error CHARACTER CODES In bit when PCRE_UTF16 is not set
 
a negative value specifies a zero terminated string If byte_order is it is assumed that the string starts off in host byte order This may be changed by byte order a non zero value of the integer to which it points means that the input starts off in host byte otherwise the opposite order is assumed BOMs in the string can change this The final byte order is passed back at the end of processing If keep_boms is not byte order mark including the zero terminator if the string was zero terminated SUBJECT STRING OFFSETS The lengths and starting offsets of subject strings must be specified in bit data and the offsets within subject strings that are returned by the matching functions are in also bit units rather than bytes NAMED SUBPATTERNS The name to number translation table that is maintained for named sub patterns uses bit characters The PCRE_UTF16 and which correspond to PCRE_UTF8 and PCRE_NO_UTF8_CHECK in the bit library In these new options define the same bits in the options word There is a discussion about the validity of UTF strings in the pcreunicode page For the otherwise If this option is given to or if the PCRE_CONFIG_UTF8 or PCRE_CONFIG_UTF32 option is given to pcre16_con the result is the PCRE_ERROR_BADOPTION error CHARACTER CODES In bit when PCRE_UTF16 is not character values are treated in the same way as in bit
 
a negative value specifies a zero terminated string If byte_order is it is assumed that the string starts off in host byte order This may be changed by byte order a non zero value of the integer to which it points means that the input starts off in host byte otherwise the opposite order is assumed BOMs in the string can change this The final byte order is passed back at the end of processing If keep_boms is not byte order mark including the zero terminator if the string was zero terminated SUBJECT STRING OFFSETS The lengths and starting offsets of subject strings must be specified in bit data and the offsets within subject strings that are returned by the matching functions are in also bit units rather than bytes NAMED SUBPATTERNS The name to number translation table that is maintained for named sub patterns uses bit characters The PCRE_UTF16 and which correspond to PCRE_UTF8 and PCRE_NO_UTF8_CHECK in the bit library In these new options define the same bits in the options word There is a discussion about the validity of UTF strings in the pcreunicode page For the otherwise If this option is given to or if the PCRE_CONFIG_UTF8 or PCRE_CONFIG_UTF32 option is given to pcre16_con the result is the PCRE_ERROR_BADOPTION error CHARACTER CODES In bit when PCRE_UTF16 is not character values are treated in the same way as in non UTF except
 
a negative value specifies a zero terminated string If byte_order is it is assumed that the string starts off in host byte order This may be changed by byte order a non zero value of the integer to which it points means that the input starts off in host byte otherwise the opposite order is assumed BOMs in the string can change this The final byte order is passed back at the end of processing If keep_boms is not byte order mark including the zero terminator if the string was zero terminated SUBJECT STRING OFFSETS The lengths and starting offsets of subject strings must be specified in bit data and the offsets within subject strings that are returned by the matching functions are in also bit units rather than bytes NAMED SUBPATTERNS The name to number translation table that is maintained for named sub patterns uses bit characters The PCRE_UTF16 and which correspond to PCRE_UTF8 and PCRE_NO_UTF8_CHECK in the bit library In these new options define the same bits in the options word There is a discussion about the validity of UTF strings in the pcreunicode page For the otherwise If this option is given to or if the PCRE_CONFIG_UTF8 or PCRE_CONFIG_UTF32 option is given to pcre16_con the result is the PCRE_ERROR_BADOPTION error CHARACTER CODES In bit when PCRE_UTF16 is not character values are treated in the same way as in non UTF of course
 
a negative value specifies a zero terminated string If byte_order is it is assumed that the string starts off in host byte order This may be changed by byte order a non zero value of the integer to which it points means that the input starts off in host byte otherwise the opposite order is assumed BOMs in the string can change this The final byte order is passed back at the end of processing If keep_boms is not byte order mark including the zero terminator if the string was zero terminated SUBJECT STRING OFFSETS The lengths and starting offsets of subject strings must be specified in bit data and the offsets within subject strings that are returned by the matching functions are in also bit units rather than bytes NAMED SUBPATTERNS The name to number translation table that is maintained for named sub patterns uses bit characters The PCRE_UTF16 and which correspond to PCRE_UTF8 and PCRE_NO_UTF8_CHECK in the bit library In these new options define the same bits in the options word There is a discussion about the validity of UTF strings in the pcreunicode page For the otherwise If this option is given to or if the PCRE_CONFIG_UTF8 or PCRE_CONFIG_UTF32 option is given to pcre16_con the result is the PCRE_ERROR_BADOPTION error CHARACTER CODES In bit when PCRE_UTF16 is not character values are treated in the same way as in non UTF of that they can range from to instead of to Character types for characters less than can therefore be influenced by the locale in the same way as before Characters greater than have only one case
 
a negative value specifies a zero terminated string If byte_order is it is assumed that the string starts off in host byte order This may be changed by byte order a non zero value of the integer to which it points means that the input starts off in host byte otherwise the opposite order is assumed BOMs in the string can change this The final byte order is passed back at the end of processing If keep_boms is not byte order mark including the zero terminator if the string was zero terminated SUBJECT STRING OFFSETS The lengths and starting offsets of subject strings must be specified in bit data and the offsets within subject strings that are returned by the matching functions are in also bit units rather than bytes NAMED SUBPATTERNS The name to number translation table that is maintained for named sub patterns uses bit characters The PCRE_UTF16 and which correspond to PCRE_UTF8 and PCRE_NO_UTF8_CHECK in the bit library In these new options define the same bits in the options word There is a discussion about the validity of UTF strings in the pcreunicode page For the otherwise If this option is given to or if the PCRE_CONFIG_UTF8 or PCRE_CONFIG_UTF32 option is given to pcre16_con the result is the PCRE_ERROR_BADOPTION error CHARACTER CODES In bit when PCRE_UTF16 is not character values are treated in the same way as in non UTF of that they can range from to instead of to Character types for characters less than can therefore be influenced by the locale in the same way as before Characters greater than have only one and no the character code is Unicode
 
a negative value specifies a zero terminated string If byte_order is it is assumed that the string starts off in host byte order This may be changed by byte order a non zero value of the integer to which it points means that the input starts off in host byte otherwise the opposite order is assumed BOMs in the string can change this The final byte order is passed back at the end of processing If keep_boms is not byte order mark including the zero terminator if the string was zero terminated SUBJECT STRING OFFSETS The lengths and starting offsets of subject strings must be specified in bit data and the offsets within subject strings that are returned by the matching functions are in also bit units rather than bytes NAMED SUBPATTERNS The name to number translation table that is maintained for named sub patterns uses bit characters The PCRE_UTF16 and which correspond to PCRE_UTF8 and PCRE_NO_UTF8_CHECK in the bit library In these new options define the same bits in the options word There is a discussion about the validity of UTF strings in the pcreunicode page For the otherwise If this option is given to or if the PCRE_CONFIG_UTF8 or PCRE_CONFIG_UTF32 option is given to pcre16_con the result is the PCRE_ERROR_BADOPTION error CHARACTER CODES In bit when PCRE_UTF16 is not character values are treated in the same way as in non UTF of that they can range from to instead of to Character types for characters less than can therefore be influenced by the locale in the same way as before Characters greater than have only one and no the character code is in the range to
 
a negative value specifies a zero terminated string If byte_order is it is assumed that the string starts off in host byte order This may be changed by byte order a non zero value of the integer to which it points means that the input starts off in host byte otherwise the opposite order is assumed BOMs in the string can change this The final byte order is passed back at the end of processing If keep_boms is not byte order mark including the zero terminator if the string was zero terminated SUBJECT STRING OFFSETS The lengths and starting offsets of subject strings must be specified in bit data and the offsets within subject strings that are returned by the matching functions are in also bit units rather than bytes NAMED SUBPATTERNS The name to number translation table that is maintained for named sub patterns uses bit characters The PCRE_UTF16 and which correspond to PCRE_UTF8 and PCRE_NO_UTF8_CHECK in the bit library In these new options define the same bits in the options word There is a discussion about the validity of UTF strings in the pcreunicode page For the otherwise If this option is given to or if the PCRE_CONFIG_UTF8 or PCRE_CONFIG_UTF32 option is given to pcre16_con the result is the PCRE_ERROR_BADOPTION error CHARACTER CODES In bit when PCRE_UTF16 is not character values are treated in the same way as in non UTF of that they can range from to instead of to Character types for characters less than can therefore be influenced by the locale in the same way as before Characters greater than have only one and no the character code is in the range with the exception of values in the range xd800 to xdfff because those are surrogate values that are used in pairs to encode values greater than xffff A UTF string can indicate its endianness by special code knows as a byte order expecting strings to be in host byte order A utility function called for if a pattern compiled with corresponding to the PCRE_UTF8_ERR codes for UTF strings that are described in the section entitled Reason codes for invalid UTF strings in the main pcreapi page The UTF errors are
 
a negative value specifies a zero terminated string If byte_order is it is assumed that the string starts off in host byte order This may be changed by byte order a non zero value of the integer to which it points means that the input starts off in host byte otherwise the opposite order is assumed BOMs in the string can change this The final byte order is passed back at the end of processing If keep_boms is not byte order mark including the zero terminator if the string was zero terminated SUBJECT STRING OFFSETS The lengths and starting offsets of subject strings must be specified in bit data and the offsets within subject strings that are returned by the matching functions are in also bit units rather than bytes NAMED SUBPATTERNS The name to number translation table that is maintained for named sub patterns uses bit characters The PCRE_UTF16 and which correspond to PCRE_UTF8 and PCRE_NO_UTF8_CHECK in the bit library In these new options define the same bits in the options word There is a discussion about the validity of UTF strings in the pcreunicode page For the otherwise If this option is given to or if the PCRE_CONFIG_UTF8 or PCRE_CONFIG_UTF32 option is given to pcre16_con the result is the PCRE_ERROR_BADOPTION error CHARACTER CODES In bit when PCRE_UTF16 is not character values are treated in the same way as in non UTF of that they can range from to instead of to Character types for characters less than can therefore be influenced by the locale in the same way as before Characters greater than have only one and no the character code is in the range with the exception of values in the range xd800 to xdfff because those are surrogate values that are used in pairs to encode values greater than xffff A UTF string can indicate its endianness by special code knows as a byte order expecting strings to be in host byte order A utility function called for if a pattern compiled with corresponding to the PCRE_UTF8_ERR codes for UTF strings that are described in the section entitled Reason codes for invalid UTF strings in the main pcreapi page The UTF errors the error text that is passed back by zero terminated CALLOUTS The subject and mark fields in the callout block that is passed to a callout function point to bit vectors TESTING The pcretest program continues to operate with bit input and output files
 
a negative value specifies a zero terminated string If byte_order is it is assumed that the string starts off in host byte order This may be changed by byte order a non zero value of the integer to which it points means that the input starts off in host byte otherwise the opposite order is assumed BOMs in the string can change this The final byte order is passed back at the end of processing If keep_boms is not byte order mark including the zero terminator if the string was zero terminated SUBJECT STRING OFFSETS The lengths and starting offsets of subject strings must be specified in bit data and the offsets within subject strings that are returned by the matching functions are in also bit units rather than bytes NAMED SUBPATTERNS The name to number translation table that is maintained for named sub patterns uses bit characters The PCRE_UTF16 and which correspond to PCRE_UTF8 and PCRE_NO_UTF8_CHECK in the bit library In these new options define the same bits in the options word There is a discussion about the validity of UTF strings in the pcreunicode page For the otherwise If this option is given to or if the PCRE_CONFIG_UTF8 or PCRE_CONFIG_UTF32 option is given to pcre16_con the result is the PCRE_ERROR_BADOPTION error CHARACTER CODES In bit when PCRE_UTF16 is not character values are treated in the same way as in non UTF of that they can range from to instead of to Character types for characters less than can therefore be influenced by the locale in the same way as before Characters greater than have only one and no the character code is in the range with the exception of values in the range xd800 to xdfff because those are surrogate values that are used in pairs to encode values greater than xffff A UTF string can indicate its endianness by special code knows as a byte order expecting strings to be in host byte order A utility function called for if a pattern compiled with corresponding to the PCRE_UTF8_ERR codes for UTF strings that are described in the section entitled Reason codes for invalid UTF strings in the main pcreapi page The UTF errors the error text that is passed back by zero terminated CALLOUTS The subject and mark fields in the callout block that is passed to a callout function point to bit vectors TESTING The pcretest program continues to operate with bit input and output but it can be used for testing the bit library If it is run with the command line option
 
a negative value specifies a zero terminated string If byte_order is it is assumed that the string starts off in host byte order This may be changed by byte order a non zero value of the integer to which it points means that the input starts off in host byte otherwise the opposite order is assumed BOMs in the string can change this The final byte order is passed back at the end of processing If keep_boms is not byte order mark including the zero terminator if the string was zero terminated SUBJECT STRING OFFSETS The lengths and starting offsets of subject strings must be specified in bit data and the offsets within subject strings that are returned by the matching functions are in also bit units rather than bytes NAMED SUBPATTERNS The name to number translation table that is maintained for named sub patterns uses bit characters The PCRE_UTF16 and which correspond to PCRE_UTF8 and PCRE_NO_UTF8_CHECK in the bit library In these new options define the same bits in the options word There is a discussion about the validity of UTF strings in the pcreunicode page For the otherwise If this option is given to or if the PCRE_CONFIG_UTF8 or PCRE_CONFIG_UTF32 option is given to pcre16_con the result is the PCRE_ERROR_BADOPTION error CHARACTER CODES In bit when PCRE_UTF16 is not character values are treated in the same way as in non UTF of that they can range from to instead of to Character types for characters less than can therefore be influenced by the locale in the same way as before Characters greater than have only one and no the character code is in the range with the exception of values in the range xd800 to xdfff because those are surrogate values that are used in pairs to encode values greater than xffff A UTF string can indicate its endianness by special code knows as a byte order expecting strings to be in host byte order A utility function called for if a pattern compiled with corresponding to the PCRE_UTF8_ERR codes for UTF strings that are described in the section entitled Reason codes for invalid UTF strings in the main pcreapi page The UTF errors the error text that is passed back by zero terminated CALLOUTS The subject and mark fields in the callout block that is passed to a callout function point to bit vectors TESTING The pcretest program continues to operate with bit input and output but it can be used for testing the bit library If it is run with the command line patterns and subject strings are con verted from bit to bit before being passed to PCRE

which it points means that the input starts off in host byte otherwise the opposite order is assumed BOMs in the string can change this The final byte order is passed back at the end of processing If keep_boms is not byte order mark including the zero terminator if the string was zero terminated SUBJECT STRING OFFSETS The lengths and starting offsets of subject strings must be specified in bit library If it is run with the command line patterns and subject strings are con verted from bit to bit before being passed to and the bit library functions are used instead of the bit ones Returned bit strings are converted to bit for output If both the bit and the bit libraries were not compiled
 
a negative value specifies a zero terminated string If byte_order is it is assumed that the string starts off in host byte order This may be changed by byte order a non zero value of the integer to which it points means that the input starts off in host byte otherwise the opposite order is assumed BOMs in the string can change this The final byte order is passed back at the end of processing If keep_boms is not byte order mark including the zero terminator if the string was zero terminated SUBJECT STRING OFFSETS The lengths and starting offsets of subject strings must be specified in bit data and the offsets within subject strings that are returned by the matching functions are in also bit units rather than bytes NAMED SUBPATTERNS The name to number translation table that is options word There is a discussion about the validity of UTF strings in the pcreunicode page For the otherwise If this option is given to or if the PCRE_CONFIG_UTF8 or PCRE_CONFIG_UTF32 option is given to pcre16_con the result is the PCRE_ERROR_BADOPTION error CHARACTER CODES In bit when PCRE_UTF16 is not character values are treated in the same way as in non UTF of that they can range from to instead of to Character types for characters less than can therefore be influenced by the locale in the same way as before Characters greater than have only one and no the character code is in the range with the exception of values in the range xd800 to xdfff because those are surrogate values that are used in pairs to encode values greater than xffff A UTF string can indicate its endianness by special code knows as a byte order expecting strings to be in host byte order A utility function called for if a pattern compiled with corresponding to the PCRE_UTF8_ERR codes for UTF strings that are described in the section entitled Reason codes for invalid UTF strings in the main pcreapi page The UTF errors the error text that is passed back by zero terminated CALLOUTS The subject and mark fields in the callout block that is passed to a callout function point to bit vectors TESTING The pcretest program continues to operate with bit input and output but it can be used for testing the bit library If it is run with the command line patterns and subject strings are con verted from bit to bit before being passed to and the bit library functions are used instead of the bit ones Returned bit strings are converted to bit for output If both the bit and the bit libraries were not pcretest defaults to bit and the option is ignored When PCRE is being the RunTest script that is called by make check uses the pcretest C option to discover which of the bit and bit libraries has been and runs the tests appro priately NOT SUPPORTED IN BIT MODE Not all the features of the bit library are available with the bit library The C and POSIX wrapper functions support only the bit and the pcregrep program is at present bit only AUTHOR Philip Hazel University Computing Service Cambridge CB2

which it points means that the input starts off in host byte otherwise the opposite order is assumed BOMs in the string can change this The final byte order is passed back at the end of processing If PCRE BIT API INDIRECTED FUNCTIONS void *(* pcre32_malloc )(size_t)
 
void(* pcre32_free )(void *)
 
void *(* pcre32_stack_malloc )(size_t)
 
void(* pcre32_stack_free )(void *)
 
int(* pcre32_callout )(pcre32_callout_block *)
 
THE PCRE BIT LIBRARY Starting with it is possible to compile a PCRE library that supports bit character including UTF as well as or instead of the original bit library This work was done by Christian Persch
 
THE PCRE BIT LIBRARY Starting with it is possible to compile a PCRE library that supports bit character including UTF as well as or instead of the original bit library This work was done by Christian based on the work done by Zoltan Herczeg for the bit library All three libraries contain identical sets of func tions
 
THE PCRE BIT LIBRARY Starting with it is possible to compile a PCRE library that supports bit character including UTF as well as or instead of the original bit library This work was done by Christian based on the work done by Zoltan Herczeg for the bit library All three libraries contain identical sets of func used in exactly the same way Only the names of the functions and the data types of their arguments and results are different To avoid over complication and reduce the documentation maintenance most of the PCRE documentation describes the bit with only occasional references to the bit and bit libraries This page describes what is different when you use the bit library but you must take care when processing any particular pattern to use functions from just one library For if you want to study a pattern that was compiled with you must do so with not and you must free the study data with pcre h It contains prototypes for all the functions in all as well as definitions of struc error etc THE LIBRARY NAME In Unix like the bit library is called libpcre32
 
a negative value specifies a zero terminated string If byte_order is it is assumed that the string starts off in host byte order This may be changed by byte order a non zero value of the integer to which it points means that the input starts off in host byte otherwise the opposite order is assumed BOMs in the string can change this The final byte order is passed back at the end of processing If keep_boms is not byte order mark including the zero terminator if the string was zero terminated SUBJECT STRING OFFSETS The lengths and starting offsets of subject strings must be specified in bit data and the offsets within subject strings that are returned by the matching functions are in also bit units rather than bytes NAMED SUBPATTERNS The name to number translation table that is maintained for named sub patterns uses bit characters The PCRE_UTF32 and PCRE_NO_UTF32_CHECK
 
it can be changed by adding a setting such as with posix malloc threshold
 
it can be changed by adding a setting such as with posix malloc offset values are used to point from one part to in the bit and bit two byte values are used for these offsets
 
it can be changed by adding a setting such as with posix malloc offset values are used to point from one part to in the bit and bit two byte values are used for these leading to a maximum size for a compiled pattern of around This is sufficient to handle all but the most gigantic patterns Nevertheless
 
it can be changed by adding a setting such as with posix malloc offset values are used to point from one part to in the bit and bit two byte values are used for these leading to a maximum size for a compiled pattern of around This is sufficient to handle all but the most gigantic patterns some people do want to process truly enormous patterns
 
it can be changed by adding a setting such as with posix malloc offset values are used to point from one part to in the bit and bit two byte values are used for these leading to a maximum size for a compiled pattern of around This is sufficient to handle all but the most gigantic patterns some people do want to process truly enormous so it is possible to compile PCRE to use three byte or four byte offsets by adding a setting such as with link size
 
it is not relevant for PCRE has a function called which it calls repeat a limit can be placed on the resources used by a single call to as described in the pcreapi documen tation The default is million
 
it is not relevant for PCRE has a function called which it calls repeat a limit can be placed on the resources used by a single call to as described in the pcreapi documen tation The default is but this can be changed by adding a setting such as with match limit
 
it defaults to the value that is set for with match which imposes no additional constraints However
 
it defaults to the value that is set for with match which imposes no additional constraints you can set a lower limit by adding
 
it defaults to the value that is set for with match which imposes no additional constraints you can set a lower limit by for with match limit recursion
 
it defaults to the value that is set for with match which imposes no additional constraints you can set a lower limit by for with match limit PCRE is built with a set of tables that are distributed in the file pcre_chartables c dist These tables are for ASCII codes only If you add enable rebuild chartables to the configure command
 
it defaults to the value that is set for with match which imposes no additional constraints you can set a lower limit by for with match limit PCRE is built with a set of tables that are distributed in the file pcre_chartables c dist These tables are for ASCII codes only If you add enable rebuild chartables to the configure the distributed tables are no longer used Instead
 
it defaults to the value that is set for with match which imposes no additional constraints you can set a lower limit by for with match limit PCRE is built with a set of tables that are distributed in the file pcre_chartables c dist These tables are for ASCII codes only If you add enable rebuild chartables to the configure the distributed tables are no longer used a program called dftables is compiled and run This outputs the source for new set of tables
 
it defaults to the value that is set for with match which imposes no additional constraints you can set a lower limit by for with match limit PCRE is built with a set of tables that are distributed in the file pcre_chartables c dist These tables are for ASCII codes only If you add enable rebuild chartables to the configure the distributed tables are no longer used a program called dftables is compiled and run This outputs the source for new set of created in the default locale of your C run time which is a superset of ASCII This is the case for most computer operating systems PCRE can
 
it defaults to the value that is set for with match which imposes no additional constraints you can set a lower limit by for with match limit PCRE is built with a set of tables that are distributed in the file pcre_chartables c dist These tables are for ASCII codes only If you add enable rebuild chartables to the configure the distributed tables are no longer used a program called dftables is compiled and run This outputs the source for new set of created in the default locale of your C run time which is a superset of ASCII This is the case for most computer operating systems PCRE how ever
 
it defaults to the value that is set for with match which imposes no additional constraints you can set a lower limit by for with match limit PCRE is built with a set of tables that are distributed in the file pcre_chartables c dist These tables are for ASCII codes only If you add enable rebuild chartables to the configure the distributed tables are no longer used a program called dftables is compiled and run This outputs the source for new set of created in the default locale of your C run time which is a superset of ASCII This is the case for most computer operating systems PCRE how be compiled to run in an EBCDIC environment by adding enable ebcdic to the configure command This setting implies enable rebuild charta bles You should only use it if you know that you are in an EBCDIC in some EBCDIC is used In such an environment you should use enable ebcdic nl25 as well as
 
it defaults to the value that is set for with match which imposes no additional constraints you can set a lower limit by for with match limit PCRE is built with a set of tables that are distributed in the file pcre_chartables c dist These tables are for ASCII codes only If you add enable rebuild chartables to the configure the distributed tables are no longer used a program called dftables is compiled and run This outputs the source for new set of created in the default locale of your C run time which is a superset of ASCII This is the case for most computer operating systems PCRE how be compiled to run in an EBCDIC environment by adding enable ebcdic to the configure command This setting implies enable rebuild charta bles You should only use it if you know that you are in an EBCDIC in some EBCDIC is used In such an environment you should use enable ebcdic nl25 as well or instead of
 
it defaults to the value that is set for with match which imposes no additional constraints you can set a lower limit by for with match limit PCRE is built with a set of tables that are distributed in the file pcre_chartables c dist These tables are for ASCII codes only If you add enable rebuild chartables to the configure the distributed tables are no longer used a program called dftables is compiled and run This outputs the source for new set of created in the default locale of your C run time which is a superset of ASCII This is the case for most computer operating systems PCRE how be compiled to run in an EBCDIC environment by adding enable ebcdic to the configure command This setting implies enable rebuild charta bles You should only use it if you know that you are in an EBCDIC in some EBCDIC is used In such an environment you should use enable ebcdic nl25 as well or instead enable ebcdic The EBCDIC character for CR has the same value as in ASCII
 
it defaults to the value that is set for with match which imposes no additional constraints you can set a lower limit by for with match limit PCRE is built with a set of tables that are distributed in the file pcre_chartables c dist These tables are for ASCII codes only If you add enable rebuild chartables to the configure the distributed tables are no longer used a program called dftables is compiled and run This outputs the source for new set of created in the default locale of your C run time which is a superset of ASCII This is the case for most computer operating systems PCRE how be compiled to run in an EBCDIC environment by adding enable ebcdic to the configure command This setting implies enable rebuild charta bles You should only use it if you know that you are in an EBCDIC in some EBCDIC is used In such an environment you should use enable ebcdic nl25 as well or instead enable ebcdic The EBCDIC character for CR has the same value as in namely
 
it defaults to the value that is set for with match which imposes no additional constraints you can set a lower limit by for with match limit PCRE is built with a set of tables that are distributed in the file pcre_chartables c dist These tables are for ASCII codes only If you add enable rebuild chartables to the configure the distributed tables are no longer used a program called dftables is compiled and run This outputs the source for new set of created in the default locale of your C run time which is a superset of ASCII This is the case for most computer operating systems PCRE how be compiled to run in an EBCDIC environment by adding enable ebcdic to the configure command This setting implies enable rebuild charta bles You should only use it if you know that you are in an EBCDIC in some EBCDIC is used In such an environment you should use enable ebcdic nl25 as well or instead enable ebcdic The EBCDIC character for CR has the same value as in Whichever of and is not chosen as LF is made to correspond to the Unicode NEL char such as enable newline is cr
 
it defaults to the value that is set for with match which imposes no additional constraints you can set a lower limit by for with match limit PCRE is built with a set of tables that are distributed in the file pcre_chartables c dist These tables are for ASCII codes only If you add enable rebuild chartables to the configure the distributed tables are no longer used a program called dftables is compiled and run This outputs the source for new set of created in the default locale of your C run time which is a superset of ASCII This is the case for most computer operating systems PCRE how be compiled to run in an EBCDIC environment by adding enable ebcdic to the configure command This setting implies enable rebuild charta bles You should only use it if you know that you are in an EBCDIC in some EBCDIC is used In such an environment you should use enable ebcdic nl25 as well or instead enable ebcdic The EBCDIC character for CR has the same value as in Whichever of and is not chosen as LF is made to correspond to the Unicode NEL char such as enable newline is and equivalent run time refer to these character values in an EBCDIC environment PCREGREP OPTIONS FOR COMPRESSED FILE SUPPORT By default

it defaults to the value that is set for with match which imposes no additional constraints you can set a lower limit by for with match limit PCRE is built with a set of tables that are distributed in the file pcre_chartables c dist These tables are for ASCII codes only If you add enable rebuild chartables to the configure the distributed tables are no longer used a program called dftables is compiled and run This outputs the source for new set of created in the default locale of your C run time which is a superset of ASCII This is the case for most computer operating systems PCRE how be compiled to run in an EBCDIC environment by adding enable ebcdic to the configure command This setting implies enable rebuild charta bles You should only use it if you know that you are in an EBCDIC in some EBCDIC is used In such an environment you should use enable ebcdic nl25 as well or instead enable ebcdic The EBCDIC character for CR has the same value as in Whichever of and is not chosen as LF is made to correspond to the Unicode NEL char such as enable newline is and equivalent run time refer to these character values in an EBCDIC environment PCREGREP OPTIONS FOR COMPRESSED FILE SUPPORT By pcregrep reads all files as plain text You can build it so that it recognizes files whose names end in gz or and reads them with libz or by adding one or both of enable pcregrep libz enable pcregrep libbz2 to the configure command These options naturally require that the rel evant libraries are installed on your system Configuration will fail if they are not PCREGREP BUFFER SIZE pcregrep uses an internal buffer to hold a window on the file it is scanning
 
it defaults to the value that is set for with match which imposes no additional constraints you can set a lower limit by for with match limit PCRE is built with a set of tables that are distributed in the file pcre_chartables c dist These tables are for ASCII codes only If you add enable rebuild chartables to the configure the distributed tables are no longer used a program called dftables is compiled and run This outputs the source for new set of created in the default locale of your C run time which is a superset of ASCII This is the case for most computer operating systems PCRE how be compiled to run in an EBCDIC environment by adding enable ebcdic to the configure command This setting implies enable rebuild charta bles You should only use it if you know that you are in an EBCDIC in some EBCDIC is used In such an environment you should use enable ebcdic nl25 as well or instead enable ebcdic The EBCDIC character for CR has the same value as in Whichever of and is not chosen as LF is made to correspond to the Unicode NEL char such as enable newline is and equivalent run time refer to these character values in an EBCDIC environment PCREGREP OPTIONS FOR COMPRESSED FILE SUPPORT By pcregrep reads all files as plain text You can build it so that it recognizes files whose names end in gz or and reads them with libz or by adding one or both of enable pcregrep libz enable pcregrep libbz2 to the configure command These options naturally require that the rel evant libraries are installed on your system Configuration will fail if they are not PCREGREP BUFFER SIZE pcregrep uses an internal buffer to hold a window on the file it is in order to be able to output before and after lines when it finds a match The size of the buffer is controlled by a parameter whose default value is The buffer itself is three times this but because of the way it is used for holding before lines

pcregrep libbz2 to the configure command These options naturally require that the rel evant libraries are installed on your system Configuration will fail if they are not PCREGREP BUFFER SIZE pcregrep uses an internal buffer to hold a window on the file it is in order to be able to output before and after lines when it finds a match The size of the buffer is controlled by a parameter whose default value is The buffer itself is three times this but because of the way it is used for holding before the long est line that is guaranteed to be processable is the parameter size You can change the default parameter value by for with pcregrep bufsize
