Here is the caller graph for this function:

The following names for option bits are defined in the pcre h header the pattern is forced to be that it is constrained to match only at the first matching point in the string that is being searched ( the"subject string"  ) const
it is not relevant for PCRE has a function called which it calls repeat a limit can be placed on the resources used by a single call to as described in the pcreapi documen tation The default is but this can be changed by adding a setting such as with match in order to restrict the maximum amount of stack ( or  heap,
if--disable-stack-for-recursion is  specified 
)
The following names for option bits are defined in the pcre h header the pattern is forced to be that it is constrained to match only at the first matching point in the string that is being which is the only way to do it in Perl PCRE_AUTO_CALLOUT If this bit is all with before each pattern item For discussion of the callout see the pcrecallout documentation PCRE_BSR_ANYCRLF PCRE_BSR_UNICODE These or or to match any Unicode newline sequence The default is specified when PCRE is built It can be overridden from within the or by set ting an option when a compiled pattern is matched PCRE_CASELESS If this bit is letters in the pattern match both upper and lower case letters It is equivalent to Perl s i and it can be changed within a pattern by PCRE always understands the concept of case for characters whose values are less so caseless matching is always possible For characters with higher the concept of case is supported if PCRE is com piled with Unicode property but not otherwise If you want to use caseless matching for characters and you must ensure that PCRE is compiled with Unicode property support as well as with UTF support PCRE_DOLLAR_ENDONLY If this bit is a dollar metacharacter in the pattern matches only at the end of the subject string Without this a dollar also matches immediately before a newline at the end of the string ( but not before any other  newlines)
PCRE AND BIT LIBRARIES As well as support for bit character PCRE also supports bit strings ( from release 8.  30)
it defaults to the value that is set for with match which imposes no additional constraints you can set a lower limit by for with match limit PCRE is built with a set of tables that are distributed in the file pcre_chartables c dist These tables are for ASCII codes only If you add enable rebuild chartables to the configure the distributed tables are no longer used a program called dftables is compiled and run This outputs the source for new set of created in the default locale of your C run time system ( This method of replacing the tables does not work if you are cross  compiling,
because dftables is run on the local host.If you need to create alternative tables when cross  compiling,
you will have to do so"by hand"  . 
)
a negative value specifies a zero terminated string If byte_order is it is assumed that the string starts off in host byte order This may be changed by byte order a non zero value of the integer to which it points means that the input starts off in host byte otherwise the opposite order is assumed BOMs in the string can change this The final byte order is passed back at the end of processing If keep_boms is not byte order mark including the zero terminator if the string was zero terminated SUBJECT STRING OFFSETS The lengths and starting offsets of subject strings must be specified in bit data and the offsets within subject strings that are returned by the matching functions are in also bit units rather than bytes NAMED SUBPATTERNS The name to number translation table that is maintained for named sub patterns uses bit characters The PCRE_UTF16 and which correspond to PCRE_UTF8 and PCRE_NO_UTF8_CHECK in the bit library In these new options define the same bits in the options word There is a discussion about the validity of UTF strings in the pcreunicode page For the otherwise If this option is given to or if the PCRE_CONFIG_UTF8 or PCRE_CONFIG_UTF32 option is given to pcre16_con the result is the PCRE_ERROR_BADOPTION error CHARACTER CODES In bit when PCRE_UTF16 is not character values are treated in the same way as in non UTF of that they can range from to instead of to Character types for characters less than can therefore be influenced by the locale in the same way as before Characters greater than have only one and no type ( such as letter or  digit)
otherwise it is set to zero PCRE_CONFIG_JITTARGET The output is a pointer to a zero terminated const char* string If JIT support is the string contains the name of the architec ture for which the JIT compiler is for example x86 ( little endian+  unaligned)

Variable Documentation

it is not the default The Unicode tables correspond to Unicode release In addition to the Perl compatible matching PCRE contains an alternative function that matches the same compiled patterns in a dif ferent way In certain the alternative function has some advantages For a discussion of the two matching see the pcrematching page PCRE is written in C and released as a C library A number of people have written wrappers and interfaces of various kinds In Google Inc have provided a comprehensive C wrapper for the bit library This is now included as part of the PCRE distribution The pcrecpp page has details of this interface Other people s contribu tions can be found in the Contrib directory at the primary FTP which or changed when the library is built The but which are not intended for use by external callers Their names all begin with _pcre_ or _pcre16_ or _pcre32_
otherwise it is set to zero This value should normally be given to the bit version of this the result is PCRE_ERROR_BADOPTION PCRE_CONFIG_UTF32 The output is an integer that is set to one if UTF support is avail able
The following names for option bits are defined in the pcre h header the pattern is forced to be that it is constrained to match only at the first matching point in the string that is being which is the only way to do it in Perl PCRE_AUTO_CALLOUT If this bit is all with before each pattern item For discussion of the callout see the pcrecallout documentation PCRE_BSR_ANYCRLF PCRE_BSR_UNICODE These or or to match any Unicode newline sequence The default is specified when PCRE is built It can be overridden from within the or by set ting an option when a compiled pattern is matched PCRE_CASELESS If this bit is letters in the pattern match both upper and lower case letters It is equivalent to Perl s i and it can be changed within a pattern by PCRE always understands the concept of case for characters whose values are less so caseless matching is always possible For characters with higher the concept of case is supported if PCRE is com piled with Unicode property but not otherwise If you want to use caseless matching for characters and above
it defaults to the value that is set for with match which imposes no additional constraints you can set a lower limit by for with match limit PCRE is built with a set of tables that are distributed in the file pcre_chartables c dist These tables are for ASCII codes only If you add enable rebuild chartables to the configure the distributed tables are no longer used a program called dftables is compiled and run This outputs the source for new set of created in the default locale of your C run time which is a superset of ASCII This is the case for most computer operating systems PCRE how be compiled to run in an EBCDIC environment by adding enable ebcdic to the configure command This setting implies enable rebuild charta bles You should only use it if you know that you are in an EBCDIC in some EBCDIC is used In such an environment you should use enable ebcdic nl25 as well or instead enable ebcdic The EBCDIC character for CR has the same value as in Whichever of and is not chosen as LF is made to correspond to the Unicode NEL char such as enable newline is and equivalent run time refer to these character values in an EBCDIC environment PCREGREP OPTIONS FOR COMPRESSED FILE SUPPORT By pcregrep reads all files as plain text You can build it so that it recognizes files whose names end in gz or and reads them with libz or by adding one or both of enable pcregrep libz enable pcregrep libbz2 to the configure command These options naturally require that the rel evant libraries are installed on your system Configuration will fail if they are not PCREGREP BUFFER SIZE pcregrep uses an internal buffer to hold a window on the file it is in order to be able to output before and after lines when it finds a match The size of the buffer is controlled by a parameter whose default value is The buffer itself is three times this but because of the way it is used for holding before the long est line that is guaranteed to be processable is the parameter size You can change the default parameter value by adding
THE PCRE BIT LIBRARY Starting with it is possible to compile a PCRE library that supports bit character including UTF as well as or instead of the original bit library This work was done by Christian based on the work done by Zoltan Herczeg for the bit library All three libraries contain identical sets of func used in exactly the same way Only the names of the functions and the data types of their arguments and results are different To avoid over complication and reduce the documentation maintenance most of the PCRE documentation describes the bit with only occasional references to the bit and bit libraries This page describes what is different when you use the bit library but you must take care when processing any particular pattern to use functions from just one library For if you want to study a pattern that was compiled with you must do so with not and you must free the study data with pcre h It contains prototypes for all the functions in all as well as definitions of struc error etc THE LIBRARY NAME In Unix like the bit library is called and can normally be accesss by adding lpcre32 to the command for linking an application that uses PCRE STRING TYPES In the bit strings are passed to PCRE library functions as vectors of bytes with the C type char *In the bit strings are passed as vectors of unsigned bit quantities The macro PCRE_UCHAR32 specifies an appropriate data and PCRE_SPTR32 is defined as const PCRE_UCHAR32 *In very many unsigned int is a bit data type When PCRE is it defines PCRE_UCHAR32 as unsigned but checks that it really is a bit data type If it is the build fails with an error message telling the maintainer to modify the definition appropriately STRUCTURE TYPES The types of the opaque structures that are used for compiled bit patterns and JIT stacks are pcre32 and pcre32_jit_stack respectively The type of the user accessible structure that is returned by and the type of the structure that is used for passing data to a callout function is pcre32_callout_block These structures contain the same with the same as their bit counterparts The only difference is that pointers to character strings are bit instead of bit types BIT FUNCTIONS For every function in the bit library there is a corresponding func tion in the bit library with a name that starts with pcre32_ instead of pcre_ The prototypes are listed above In addition
a negative value specifies a zero terminated string If byte_order is it is assumed that the string starts off in host byte order This may be changed by byte order a non zero value of the integer to which it points means that the input starts off in host byte otherwise the opposite order is assumed Again
they operate in a different and are not Perl compatible This alternative has advan tages and disadvantages compared with the standard algorithm

The following names for option bits are defined in the pcre h header the pattern is forced to be anchored
otherwise it is set to zero PCRE_CONFIG_JITTARGET The output is a pointer to a zero terminated const char *string If JIT support is the string contains the name of the architec ture for which the JIT compiler is for example the result is NULL PCRE_CONFIG_NEWLINE The output is an integer whose value specifies the default character sequence that is recognized as meaning newline The values that are supported in ASCII Unicode environments for for for and for ANY In EBCDIC ANYCRLF
This file contains a concatenation of the PCRE man converted to plain text format for ease of searching with a text or for use on systems that do not have a man page processor The small individual files that give synopses of each function in the library have not been included Neither has the pcredemo program There are separate text files for the pcregrep and pcretest commands with library names and libpcre32 January saw the first release of a new API
this overrides any other settings See the pcrepattern page for details of the special character sequences In the PCRE documentation the word newline is used to mean the char acter or pair of characters that indicate a line break The choice of newline convention affects the handling of the and dollar the handling of CRLF is a recognized line ending the match position advance ment for a non anchored pattern There is more detail about this in the section on nor does it affect what R which is controlled in a similar but by separate options MULTITHREADING The PCRE functions can be used in multi threading applications
otherwise it is set to zero PCRE_CONFIG_JITTARGET The output is a pointer to a zero terminated const char *string If JIT support is the string contains the name of the architec ture for which the JIT compiler is for example the result is NULL PCRE_CONFIG_NEWLINE The output is an integer whose value specifies the default character sequence that is recognized as meaning newline The values that are supported in ASCII Unicode environments are
in these the offset passed back is the length of the pattern Note that the offset is in data not even in a UTF mode It may sometimes point into the middle of a UTF or UTF char acter If and the error codeptr argument is not a non zero error code number is returned via this argument in the event of an error This is in addition to the textual error message Error codes and messages are listed below If the final argument
they operate in a different and are not Perl compatible This alternative has advan tages and disadvantages compared with the standard and these are described below When there is only one possible way in which a given subject string can match a the two algorithms give the same answer A difference arises
PCRE AND BIT LIBRARIES As well as support for bit character PCRE also supports bit by means of two additional libraries They can be built as well as
it defaults to the value that is set for with match which imposes no additional constraints you can set a lower limit by for with match limit PCRE is built with a set of tables that are distributed in the file pcre_chartables c dist These tables are for ASCII codes only If you add enable rebuild chartables to the configure the distributed tables are no longer used a program called dftables is compiled and run This outputs the source for new set of created in the default locale of your C run time which is a superset of ASCII This is the case for most computer operating systems PCRE how be compiled to run in an EBCDIC environment by adding enable ebcdic to the configure command This setting implies enable rebuild charta bles You should only use it if you know that you are in an EBCDIC in some EBCDIC is used In such an environment you should use enable ebcdic nl25 as well or instead enable ebcdic The EBCDIC character for CR has the same value as in ASCII
otherwise it is set to zero PCRE_CONFIG_JITTARGET The output is a pointer to a zero terminated const char *string If JIT support is available
a value of means that R matches only or CRLF The default can be overridden when a pat tern is compiled or matched PCRE_CONFIG_LINK_SIZE The output is an integer that contains the number of bytes used for internal linkage in compiled regular expressions For the bit the value can be
The following names for option bits are defined in the pcre h header the pattern is forced to be that it is constrained to match only at the first matching point in the string that is being which is the only way to do it in Perl PCRE_AUTO_CALLOUT If this bit is all with before each pattern item For discussion of the callout see the pcrecallout documentation PCRE_BSR_ANYCRLF PCRE_BSR_UNICODE These or or to match any Unicode newline sequence The default is specified when PCRE is built It can be overridden from within the or by set ting an option when a compiled pattern is matched PCRE_CASELESS If this bit is letters in the pattern match both upper and lower case letters It is equivalent to Perl s i and it can be changed within a pattern by PCRE always understands the concept of case for characters whose values are less so caseless matching is always possible For characters with higher the concept of case is supported if PCRE is com piled with Unicode property but not otherwise If you want to use caseless matching for characters and you must ensure that PCRE is compiled with Unicode property support as well as with UTF support PCRE_DOLLAR_ENDONLY If this bit is a dollar metacharacter in the pattern matches only at the end of the subject string Without this a dollar also matches immediately before a newline at the end of the and no way to set it within a pattern PCRE_DOTALL If this bit is a dot metacharacter in the pattern matches a char acter of any including one that indicates a newline it only ever matches one even if newlines are coded as CRLF Without this a dot does not match when the current position is at a newline This option is equivalent to Perl s s and it can be changed within a pattern by independent of the set ting of this option PCRE_DUPNAMES If this bit is names used to identify capturing subpatterns need not be unique This can be helpful for certain types of pattern when it is known that only one instance of the named subpattern can ever be matched There are more details of named subpatterns below
a negative value specifies a zero terminated string If byte_order is it is assumed that the string starts off in host byte order This may be changed by byte order a non zero value of the integer to which it points means that the input starts off in host byte otherwise the opposite order is assumed BOMs in the string can change this The final byte order is passed back at the end of processing If keep_boms is not byte order mark including the zero terminator if the string was zero terminated SUBJECT STRING OFFSETS The lengths and starting offsets of subject strings must be specified in bit data and the offsets within subject strings that are returned by the matching functions are in also bit units rather than bytes NAMED SUBPATTERNS The name to number translation table that is maintained for named sub patterns uses bit characters The PCRE_UTF32 and which correspond to PCRE_UTF8 and PCRE_NO_UTF8_CHECK in the bit library In these new options define the same bits in the options word There is a discussion about the validity of UTF strings in the pcreunicode page For the otherwise If this option is given to or if the PCRE_CONFIG_UTF8 or PCRE_CONFIG_UTF16 option is given to pcre32_con the result is the PCRE_ERROR_BADOPTION error CHARACTER CODES In bit when PCRE_UTF32 is not character values are treated in the same way as in non UTF of that they can range from to instead of to Charac ter types for characters less than can therefore be influenced by the locale in the same way as before Characters greater than have only one and no the character code is in the range with the exception of values in the range xd800 to xdfff because those are surrogate values that are ill formed in UTF A UTF string can indicate its endianness by special code knows as a byte order expecting strings to be in host byte order A utility function called for if a pattern compiled with corresponding to the PCRE_UTF8_ERR codes for UTF strings that are described in the section entitled Reason codes for invalid UTF strings in the main pcreapi page The UTF errors the error text that is passed back by zero terminated CALLOUTS The subject and mark fields in the callout block that is passed to a callout function point to bit vectors TESTING The pcretest program continues to operate with bit input and output but it can be used for testing the bit library If it is run with the command line patterns and subject strings are con verted from bit to bit before being passed to and the bit library functions are used instead of the bit ones Returned bit strings are converted to bit for output If both the bit and the bit libraries were not pcretest defaults to bit and the option is ignored When PCRE is being the RunTest script that is called by make check uses the pcretest C option to discover which of the bit
PCRE BIT
Either of the functions via which a numerical error code can be returned To avoid too much we refer just to but the information applies equally to and is passed in the pattern argument A pointer to a single block of memory that is obtained via pcre_malloc is returned This contains the compiled code and related data The pcre type is defined for the returned block
it defaults to the value that is set for with match which imposes no additional constraints you can set a lower limit by for with match limit PCRE is built with a set of tables that are distributed in the file pcre_chartables c dist These tables are for ASCII codes only If you add enable rebuild chartables to the configure the distributed tables are no longer used a program called dftables is compiled and run This outputs the source for new set of created in the default locale of your C run time which is a superset of ASCII This is the case for most computer operating systems PCRE how be By pcregrep reads all files as plain text You can build it so that it recognizes files whose names end in gz or and reads them with libz or by adding one or both of enable pcregrep libz enable pcregrep libbz2 to the configure command These options naturally require that the rel evant libraries are installed on your system Configuration will fail if they are not PCREGREP BUFFER SIZE pcregrep uses an internal buffer to hold a window on the file it is in order to be able to output before and after lines when it finds a match The size of the buffer is controlled by a parameter whose default value is The buffer itself is three times this but because of the way it is used for holding before the long est line that is guaranteed to be processable is the parameter size You can change the default parameter value by for with pcregrep bufsize

to the configure command. The caller of pcregrep can
configure
it is run only when the default link size of is and the thirteenth test is run only when JIT support is not available They test some JIT specific features such as information output from pcretest about JIT compilation The and sixteenth tests are run only in bit and the and nineteenth tests are run only in bit mode These are tests that generate different output in the two modes They are for general UTF and Unicode property respectively The twentieth test is run only in bit mode It tests some specific bit features of the DFA matching engine The twenty first and twenty second tests are run only in bit when the link size is set to for the bit library They test reloading pre compiled patterns The twenty third and twenty fourth tests are run only in bit mode They are for general and UTF respectively The twenty fifth and twenty sixth tests are run only in bit mode They are for general and UTF respectively Character tables For PCRE uses four tables for manipulating and identifying characters whose code point values are less than The final argument of the a set of default tables that is built into the binary is used The source file called pcre_chartables c contains the default set of tables By this is created as a copy of pcre_chartables c which contains tables for ASCII coding if enable rebuild chartables is specified for configure

PCRE AND BIT LIBRARIES As well as support for bit character PCRE also supports bit by means of two additional libraries They can be built as well or instead the bit library To avoid too much complication

they just use different data types for their arguments and and their names start with pcre16_ or pcre32_ instead of pcre_ For every option that has UTF8 in its there are corresponding bit and bit names with UTF8 replaced by UTF16 or respectively This facility is in fact just cosmetic
PCRE AND BIT LIBRARIES As well as support for bit character PCRE also supports bit by means of two additional libraries They can be built as well or instead the bit library To avoid too much this document describes the bit versions of the with only occasional references to the bit and bit libraries The bit and bit functions operate in the same way as their bit counterparts
a negative value specifies a zero terminated string If byte_order is it is assumed that the string starts off in host byte order This may be changed by byte order a non zero value of the integer to which it points means that the input starts off in host byte otherwise the opposite order is assumed BOMs in the string can change this The final byte order is passed back at the end of processing If keep_boms is not byte order mark including the zero terminator if the string was zero terminated SUBJECT STRING OFFSETS The lengths and starting offsets of subject strings must be specified in bit data and the offsets within subject strings that are returned by the matching functions are in also bit units rather than bytes NAMED SUBPATTERNS The name to number translation table that is maintained for named sub patterns uses bit characters The PCRE_UTF32 and which correspond to PCRE_UTF8 and PCRE_NO_UTF8_CHECK in the bit library In these new options define the same bits in the options word There is a discussion about the validity of UTF strings in the pcreunicode page For the otherwise If this option is given to or if the PCRE_CONFIG_UTF8 or PCRE_CONFIG_UTF16 option is given to pcre32_con the result is the PCRE_ERROR_BADOPTION error CHARACTER CODES In bit when PCRE_UTF32 is not character values are treated in the same way as in non UTF of course
it defaults to the value that is set for with match which imposes no additional constraints you can set a lower limit by for with match limit PCRE is built with a set of tables that are distributed in the file pcre_chartables c dist These tables are for ASCII codes only If you add enable rebuild chartables to the configure the distributed tables are no longer used a program called dftables is compiled and run This outputs the source for new set of created in the default locale of your C run time which is a superset of ASCII This is the case for most computer operating systems PCRE how be compiled to run in an EBCDIC environment by adding enable ebcdic to the configure command This setting implies enable rebuild charta bles You should only use it if you know that you are in an EBCDIC in some EBCDIC is used In such an environment you should use enable ebcdic nl25 as well or instead enable ebcdic The EBCDIC character for CR has the same value as in Whichever of and is not chosen as LF is made to correspond to the Unicode NEL char such as enable newline is cr
a value of means that R matches only CR
The following names for option bits are defined in the pcre h header the pattern is forced to be that it is constrained to match only at the first matching point in the string that is being which is the only way to do it in Perl PCRE_AUTO_CALLOUT If this bit is all with before each pattern item For discussion of the callout see the pcrecallout documentation PCRE_BSR_ANYCRLF PCRE_BSR_UNICODE These or CRLF
it defaults to the value that is set for with match which imposes no additional constraints you can set a lower limit by for with match limit PCRE is built with a set of tables that are distributed in the file pcre_chartables c dist These tables are for ASCII codes only If you add enable rebuild chartables to the configure the distributed tables are no longer used a program called dftables is compiled and run This outputs the source for new set of created in the default locale of your C run time which is a superset of ASCII This is the case for most computer operating systems PCRE how be compiled to run in an EBCDIC environment by adding enable ebcdic to the configure command This setting implies enable rebuild charta bles You should only use it if you know that you are in an EBCDIC in some EBCDIC is used In such an environment you should use enable ebcdic nl25 as well or instead enable ebcdic The EBCDIC character for CR has the same value as in Whichever of and is not chosen as LF is made to correspond to the Unicode NEL char such as enable newline is and equivalent run time refer to these character values in an EBCDIC environment PCREGREP OPTIONS FOR COMPRESSED FILE SUPPORT By default
this overrides any other settings See the pcrepattern page for details of the special character sequences In the PCRE documentation the word newline is used to mean the char acter or pair of characters that indicate a line break The choice of newline convention affects the handling of the and dollar the handling of CRLF is a recognized line ending the match position advance ment for a non anchored pattern There is more detail about this in the section on nor does it affect what R which is controlled in a similar but by separate options MULTITHREADING The PCRE functions can be used in multi threading with the proviso that the memory management functions pointed to by and and the callout and stack checking functions pointed to by pcre_callout and are shared by all threads The compiled form of a regular expression is not altered during match so the same compiled pattern can safely be used by several threads at once If the just in time optimization feature is being it needs sepa rate memory stack areas for each thread See the pcrejit documentation for more details SAVING PRECOMPILED PATTERNS FOR LATER USE The compiled form of a regular expression can be saved and re used at a later possibly by a different and even on a host other than the one on which it was compiled Details are given in the pcreprecompile documentation
this overrides any other settings See the pcrepattern page for details of the special character sequences In the PCRE documentation the word newline is used to mean the char acter or pair of characters that indicate a line break The choice of newline convention affects the handling of the dot

otherwise it is set to zero PCRE_CONFIG_JITTARGET The output is a pointer to a zero terminated const char *string If JIT support is the string contains the name of the architec ture for which the JIT compiler is for example the result is NULL PCRE_CONFIG_NEWLINE The output is an integer whose value specifies the default character sequence that is recognized as meaning newline The values that are supported in ASCII Unicode environments for for for and for ANY In EBCDIC environments
const char* error
Either of the functions errorcodeptr
a negative value specifies a zero terminated string If byte_order is it is assumed that the string starts off in host byte order This may be changed by byte order a non zero value of the integer to which it points means that the input starts off in host byte otherwise the opposite order is assumed BOMs in the string can change this The final byte order is passed back at the end of processing If keep_boms is not byte order mark including the zero terminator if the string was zero terminated SUBJECT STRING OFFSETS The lengths and starting offsets of subject strings must be specified in bit data and the offsets within subject strings that are returned by the matching functions are in also bit units rather than bytes NAMED SUBPATTERNS The name to number translation table that is maintained for named sub patterns uses bit characters The PCRE_UTF16 and which correspond to PCRE_UTF8 and PCRE_NO_UTF8_CHECK in the bit library In these new options define the same bits in the options word There is a discussion about the validity of UTF strings in the pcreunicode page For the otherwise If this option is given to or if the PCRE_CONFIG_UTF8 or PCRE_CONFIG_UTF32 option is given to pcre16_con the result is the PCRE_ERROR_BADOPTION error CHARACTER CODES In bit when PCRE_UTF16 is not character values are treated in the same way as in non UTF of that they can range from to instead of to Character types for characters less than can therefore be influenced by the locale in the same way as before Characters greater than have only one and no the character code is in the range with the exception of values in the range xd800 to xdfff because those are surrogate values that are used in pairs to encode values greater than xffff A UTF string can indicate its endianness by special code knows as a byte order expecting strings to be in host byte order A utility function called for if a pattern compiled with corresponding to the PCRE_UTF8_ERR codes for UTF strings that are described in the section entitled Reason codes for invalid UTF strings in the main pcreapi page The UTF errors the error text that is passed back by zero terminated CALLOUTS The subject and mark fields in the callout block that is passed to a callout function point to bit vectors TESTING The pcretest program continues to operate with bit input and output but it can be used for testing the bit library If it is run with the command line patterns and subject strings are con verted from bit to bit before being passed to and the bit library functions are used instead of the bit ones Returned bit strings are converted to bit for output If both the bit and the bit libraries were not pcretest defaults to bit and the option is ignored When PCRE is being the RunTest script that is called by make check uses the pcretest C option to discover which of the bit and bit libraries has been and runs the tests appro priately NOT SUPPORTED IN BIT MODE Not all the features of the bit library are available with the bit library The C and POSIX wrapper functions support only the bit and the pcregrep program is at present bit only AUTHOR Philip Hazel University Computing Service Cambridge England they operate in a different and are not Perl compatible This alternative has advan tages and disadvantages compared with the standard and these are described below When there is only one possible way in which a given subject string can match a the two algorithms give the same answer A difference when there are multiple possibilities For example

it is not the default The Unicode tables correspond to Unicode release In addition to the Perl compatible matching PCRE contains an alternative function that matches the same compiled patterns in a dif ferent way In certain the alternative function has some advantages For a discussion of the two matching see the pcrematching page PCRE is written in C and released as a C library A number of people have written wrappers and interfaces of various kinds In Google Inc have provided a comprehensive C wrapper for the bit library This is now included as part of the PCRE distribution The pcrecpp page has details of this interface Other people s contribu tions can be found in the Contrib directory at the primary FTP which excluded

THE PCRE BIT LIBRARY Starting with it is possible to compile a PCRE library that supports bit character including UTF as well as or instead of the original bit library This work was done by Christian based on the work done by Zoltan Herczeg for the bit library All three libraries contain identical sets of func used in exactly the same way Only the names of the functions and the data types of their arguments and results are different To avoid over complication and reduce the documentation maintenance most of the PCRE documentation describes the bit with only occasional references to the bit and bit libraries This page describes what is different when you use the bit library but you must take care when processing any particular pattern to use functions from just one library For if you want to study a pattern that was compiled with you must do so with not and you must free the study data with pcre h It contains prototypes for all the functions in all as well as definitions of struc error etc THE LIBRARY NAME In Unix like the bit library is called and can normally be accesss by adding lpcre32 to the command for linking an application that uses PCRE STRING TYPES In the bit strings are passed to PCRE library functions as vectors of bytes with the C type char *In the bit strings are passed as vectors of unsigned bit quantities The macro PCRE_UCHAR32 specifies an appropriate data and PCRE_SPTR32 is defined as const PCRE_UCHAR32 *In very many unsigned int is a bit data type When PCRE is it defines PCRE_UCHAR32 as unsigned but checks that it really is a bit data type If it is the build fails with an error message telling the maintainer to modify the definition appropriately STRUCTURE TYPES The types of the opaque structures that are used for compiled bit patterns and JIT stacks are pcre32 and pcre32_jit_stack respectively The type of the user accessible structure that is returned by and the type of the structure that is used for passing data to a callout function is pcre32_callout_block These structures contain the same fields
The following names for option bits are defined in the pcre h header file
it does not apply to patterns speci fied by any of the include or exclude options line line regexp Force the patterns to be require them to match entire lines This is equivalent to having and characters at the start and end of each alternative branch in every pattern This option applies only to the patterns that are matched against the contents of files
Initial value:
=word
Specify how binary files are to be processed. If the word is
"binary" (the default)
be
a value of means that R matches only or CRLF The default can be overridden when a pat tern is compiled or matched PCRE_CONFIG_LINK_SIZE The output is an integer that contains the number of bytes used for internal linkage in compiled regular expressions For the bit the value can be

THE PCRE BIT LIBRARY Starting with it is possible to compile a PCRE library that supports bit character including UTF as well as or instead of the original bit library This work was done by Christian based on the work done by Zoltan Herczeg for the bit library All three libraries contain identical sets of func used in exactly the same way Only the names of the functions and the data types of their arguments and results are different To avoid over complication and reduce the documentation maintenance most of the PCRE documentation describes the bit with only occasional references to the bit and bit libraries This page describes what is different when you use the bit library but you must take care when processing any particular pattern to use functions from just one library For if you want to study a pattern that was compiled with you must do so with not and you must free the study data with pcre h It contains prototypes for all the functions in all as well as definitions of flags
otherwise it is set to zero This value should normally be given to the bit version of this function
PCRE AND BIT LIBRARIES As well as support for bit character PCRE also supports bit by means of two additional libraries They can be built as well or instead the bit library To avoid too much this document describes the bit versions of the functions
the default is This limit does not take into account the stack that may already be used by the calling applica tion For finer control over compilation stack you can set a pointer to an external checking function in pcre_stack_guard PCRE_CONFIG_MATCH_LIMIT The output is a long integer that gives the default limit for the num ber of internal matching function calls in a pcre_stack_malloc and pcre_stack_free are called to manage memory blocks on the heap
The following names for option bits are defined in the pcre h header the pattern is forced to be that it is constrained to match only at the first matching point in the string that is being which is the only way to do it in Perl PCRE_AUTO_CALLOUT If this bit is all with before each pattern item For discussion of the callout see the pcrecallout documentation PCRE_BSR_ANYCRLF PCRE_BSR_UNICODE These or or to match any Unicode newline sequence The default is specified when PCRE is built It can be overridden from within the or by set ting an option when a compiled pattern is matched PCRE_CASELESS If this bit is letters in the pattern match both upper and lower case letters It is equivalent to Perl s i and it can be changed within a pattern by PCRE always understands the concept of case for characters whose values are less so caseless matching is always possible For characters with higher the concept of case is supported if PCRE is com piled with Unicode property but not otherwise If you want to use caseless matching for characters and you must ensure that PCRE is compiled with Unicode property support as well as with UTF support PCRE_DOLLAR_ENDONLY If this bit is a dollar metacharacter in the pattern matches only at the end of the subject string Without this a dollar also matches immediately before a newline at the end of the and no way to set it within a pattern PCRE_DOTALL If this bit is a dot metacharacter in the pattern matches a char acter of any including one that indicates a newline However
they operate in a different and are not Perl compatible This alternative has advan tages and disadvantages compared with the standard and these are described below When there is only one possible way in which a given subject string can match a the two algorithms give the same answer A difference however
this overrides any other settings See the pcrepattern page for details of the special character sequences In the PCRE documentation the word newline is used to mean the char acter or pair of characters that indicate a line break The choice of newline convention affects the handling of the and dollar the handling of CRLF is a recognized line ending the match position advance ment for a non anchored pattern There is more detail about this in the section on nor does it affect what R which is controlled in a similar but by separate options MULTITHREADING The PCRE functions can be used in multi threading with the proviso that the memory management functions pointed to by and and the callout and stack checking functions pointed to by pcre_callout and are shared by all threads The compiled form of a regular expression is not altered during match ing
it defaults to the value that is set for with match which imposes no additional constraints you can set a lower limit by for with match limit PCRE is built with a set of tables that are distributed in the file pcre_chartables c dist These tables are for ASCII codes only If you add enable rebuild chartables to the configure the distributed tables are no longer used Instead

THE PCRE BIT LIBRARY Starting with it is possible to compile a PCRE library that supports bit character including UTF as well as or instead of the original bit library The majority of the work to make this possible was done by Zoltan Herczeg The two libraries contain identical sets of used in exactly the same way Only the names of the functions and the data types of their argu ments and results are different To avoid over complication and reduce the documentation maintenance most of the PCRE documentation describes the bit with only occasional references to the bit library This page describes what is different when you use the bit library but you must take care when processing any particular pattern to use func tions from just one library For if you want to study a pat tern that was compiled with you must do so with not and you must free the study data with pcre h It contains prototypes for all the functions in all as well as definitions of struc error etc THE LIBRARY NAME In Unix like the bit library is called libpcre16

THE PCRE BIT LIBRARY Starting with it is possible to compile a PCRE library that supports bit character including UTF as well as or instead of the original bit library This work was done by Christian based on the work done by Zoltan Herczeg for the bit library All three libraries contain identical sets of func used in exactly the same way Only the names of the functions and the data types of their arguments and results are different To avoid over complication and reduce the documentation maintenance most of the PCRE documentation describes the bit with only occasional references to the bit and bit libraries This page describes what is different when you use the bit library but you must take care when processing any particular pattern to use functions from just one library For if you want to study a pattern that was compiled with you must do so with not and you must free the study data with pcre h It contains prototypes for all the functions in all as well as definitions of struc error etc THE LIBRARY NAME In Unix like the bit library is called libpcre32
it can be changed by adding a setting such as with posix malloc offset values are used to point from one part to in the bit and bit two byte values are used for these leading to a maximum size for a compiled pattern of around This is sufficient to handle all but the most gigantic patterns some people do want to process truly enormous so it is possible to compile PCRE to use three byte or four byte offsets by adding a setting such as with link or For the bit a value of is rounded up to In these libraries
a value of means that R matches only or CRLF The default can be overridden when a pat tern is compiled or matched PCRE_CONFIG_LINK_SIZE The output is an integer that contains the number of bytes used for internal linkage in compiled regular expressions For the bit the value can or For the bit the value is either or and is still a number of bytes For the bit library

=500000
to the configure command. This setting has no effect on the
pcre_dfa_exec() matching function.
In some environments it is desirable to limit the depth of recursive
calls of match() more strictly than the total number of calls
environments
it is not the default The Unicode tables correspond to Unicode release In addition to the Perl compatible matching PCRE contains an alternative function that matches the same compiled patterns in a dif ferent way In certain the alternative function has some advantages For a discussion of the two matching see the pcrematching page PCRE is written in C and released as a C library A number of people have written wrappers and interfaces of various kinds In Google Inc have provided a comprehensive C wrapper for the bit library This is now included as part of the PCRE distribution The pcrecpp page has details of this interface Other people s contribu tions can be found in the Contrib directory at the primary FTP which or changed when the library is built The but which are not intended for use by external callers Their names all begin with _pcre_ or _pcre16_ or which hopefully will not provoke any name clashes In some environments
Definition: pcre.txt:100
configure
it is run only when the default link size of is and the thirteenth test is run only when JIT support is not available They test some JIT specific features such as information output from pcretest about JIT compilation The and sixteenth tests are run only in bit and the and nineteenth tests are run only in bit mode These are tests that generate different output in the two modes They are for general UTF and Unicode property respectively The twentieth test is run only in bit mode It tests some specific bit features of the DFA matching engine The twenty first and twenty second tests are run only in bit when the link size is set to for the bit library They test reloading pre compiled patterns The twenty third and twenty fourth tests are run only in bit mode They are for general and UTF respectively The twenty fifth and twenty sixth tests are run only in bit mode They are for general and UTF respectively Character tables For PCRE uses four tables for manipulating and identifying characters whose code point values are less than The final argument of the a set of default tables that is built into the binary is used The source file called pcre_chartables c contains the default set of tables By this is created as a copy of pcre_chartables c which contains tables for ASCII coding if enable rebuild chartables is specified for configure

matching
in the same way as other grep commands but it uses the PCRE regular expression library to support patterns that are compatible with the regular expressions of Perl See or whether supplied on the command line or in a separate are given without delimiters For by surrounding a pattern with as is common in Perl they are interpreted as part of the pattern Quotes can of course be used to delimit patterns on the command line because they are interpreted by the and indeed quotes are required if a pattern contains white space or shell metacharacters The first argument that follows any option settings is treated as the single pattern to be matched when neither e nor f is present Con when one or both of these options are used to specify pat all arguments are treated as path names At least one of or an argument pattern must be provided If no files are pcregrep reads the standard input The stan dard input can also be referenced by a name consisting of a single hyphen For each line that matches a pattern is copied to the standard and if there is more than one the file name is output at the start of each followed by a colon there are options that can change how pcregrep behaves In the M option makes it possible to search for patterns that span line boundaries What defines a line boundary is controlled by the with the default default being A block of memory three times this size is whichever is the greater BUFSIZ is defined in< stdio.h > When there is more than one each pattern is applied to each line in the order in which they are except that all the e patterns are tried before the f patterns By as soon as one pattern matches a no further patterns are considered if or if only matching

to
a negative value specifies a zero terminated string If byte_order is it is assumed that the string starts off in host byte order This may be changed by byte order a non zero value of the integer to which it points means that the input starts off in host byte otherwise the opposite order is assumed BOMs in the string can change this The final byte order is passed back at the end of processing If keep_boms is not byte order mark including the zero terminator if the string was zero terminated SUBJECT STRING OFFSETS The lengths and starting offsets of subject strings must be specified in bit data and the offsets within subject strings that are returned by the matching functions are in also bit units rather than bytes NAMED SUBPATTERNS The name to number translation table that is maintained for named sub patterns uses bit characters The PCRE_UTF16 and which correspond to PCRE_UTF8 and PCRE_NO_UTF8_CHECK in the bit library In these new options define the same bits in the options word There is a discussion about the validity of UTF strings in the pcreunicode page For the otherwise If this option is given to or if the PCRE_CONFIG_UTF8 or PCRE_CONFIG_UTF32 option is given to pcre16_con the result is the PCRE_ERROR_BADOPTION error CHARACTER CODES In bit when PCRE_UTF16 is not character values are treated in the same way as in non UTF of that they can range from to instead of to Character types for characters less than can therefore be influenced by the locale in the same way as before Characters greater than have only one and no the character code is in the range to

lines that would have been out put Each file name is output on a separate line Searching normally stops as soon as a matching line is found in a file if the matching continues in order to obtain the correct and those files that have at least one match are listed along with their counts Using this option with c is a way of sup pressing the listing of files with no matches standard input is used There is no short form for this option line buffered When this option is input is read and processed line by and the output is flushed after each write By input is read in large unless pcregrep can determine that it is reading from a its use will affect perfor and the show each match as a line the offset from the start of the and a length The line number is terminated by a and the offset and length are separated by a comma In this no context is shown That the and C options are ignored If there is more than one match in a each of them is shown sepa rately This option is mutually exclusive with file offsets and only matching the PCRE library s leading in some cases to a pro gram crash if not enough is available Other patterns may take a very long time to search for all possible matching strings The but which have a very large number of possibilities in their search trees The classic example is a pattern that uses nested unlimited repeats PCRE uses a func tion called which has the effect of limiting the amount of backtracking that can take place The recursion limit option is similar to match but instead of limiting the total number of times that it limits the depth of recursive calls

setting
the caller of PCRE can change the selection at run time The default newline indicator is a single LF respectively If you specify enable newline is cr or enable newline is some of the standard tests will because the lines in the test files end with LF Even if the files are edited to change the line there are likely to be some failures With enable newline is anycrlf or enable newline is many tests should but there may be some failures By the sequence R in a pattern matches any Unicode line ending sequence This is independent of the option specifying what PCRE considers to be the end of a the caller of PCRE can restrict R to match only or CRLF You can make this the default by adding enable bsr anycrlf to the configure PCRE uses for with posix malloc but you can change it by setting

THE PCRE BIT LIBRARY Starting with it is possible to compile a PCRE library that supports bit character including UTF as well as or instead of the original bit library This work was done by Christian based on the work done by Zoltan Herczeg for the bit library All three libraries contain identical sets of func used in exactly the same way Only the names of the functions and the data types of their arguments and results are different To avoid over complication and reduce the documentation maintenance load

THE PCRE BIT LIBRARY Starting with it is possible to compile a PCRE library that supports bit character including UTF as well as or instead of the original bit library This work was done by Christian based on the work done by Zoltan Herczeg for the bit library All three libraries contain identical sets of func used in exactly the same way Only the names of the functions and the data types of their arguments and results are different To avoid over complication and reduce the documentation maintenance most of the PCRE documentation describes the bit with only occasional references to the bit and bit libraries This page describes what is different when you use the bit library but you must take care when processing any particular pattern to use functions from just one library For if you want to study a pattern that was compiled with you must do so with not and you must free the study data with pcre h It contains prototypes for all the functions in all as well as definitions of struc error etc THE LIBRARY NAME In Unix like the bit library is called and can normally be accesss by adding lpcre32 to the command for linking an application that uses PCRE STRING TYPES In the bit strings are passed to PCRE library functions as vectors of bytes with the C type char* In the bit strings are passed as vectors of unsigned bit quantities The macro PCRE_UCHAR32 specifies an appropriate data and PCRE_SPTR32 is defined as const PCRE_UCHAR32* In very many unsigned int is a bit data type When PCRE is it defines PCRE_UCHAR32 as unsigned but checks that it really is a bit data type If it is the build fails with an error message telling the maintainer to modify the definition appropriately STRUCTURE TYPES The types of the opaque structures that are used for compiled bit patterns and JIT stacks are pcre32 and pcre32_jit_stack respectively The type of the user accessible structure that is returned by and the type of the structure that is used for passing data to a callout function is pcre32_callout_block These structures contain the same with the same names
it can be changed by adding a setting such as with posix malloc offset values are used to point from one part to in the bit and bit two byte values are used for these leading to a maximum size for a compiled pattern of around This is sufficient to handle all but the most gigantic patterns Nevertheless
otherwise it is set to zero PCRE_CONFIG_JITTARGET The output is a pointer to a zero terminated const char* string If JIT support is the string contains the name of the architec ture for which the JIT compiler is for example the result is NULL PCRE_CONFIG_NEWLINE The output is an integer whose value specifies the default character sequence that is recognized as meaning newline The values that are supported in ASCII Unicode environments for for for and for ANY In EBCDIC and ANY yield the same values the value for LF is normally
THE PCRE BIT LIBRARY Starting with it is possible to compile a PCRE library that supports bit character including UTF as well as or instead of the original bit library This work was done by Christian based on the work done by Zoltan Herczeg for the bit library All three libraries contain identical sets of func used in exactly the same way Only the names of the functions and the data types of their arguments and results are different To avoid over complication and reduce the documentation maintenance most of the PCRE documentation describes the bit with only occasional references to the bit and bit libraries This page describes what is different when you use the bit library but you must take care when processing any particular pattern to use functions from just one library For if you want to study a pattern that was compiled with you must do so with not and you must free the study data with pcre h It contains prototypes for all the functions in all as well as definitions of struc error etc THE LIBRARY NAME In Unix like the bit library is called and can normally be accesss by adding lpcre32 to the command for linking an application that uses PCRE STRING TYPES In the bit strings are passed to PCRE library functions as vectors of bytes with the C type char *In the bit strings are passed as vectors of unsigned bit quantities The macro PCRE_UCHAR32 specifies an appropriate data and PCRE_SPTR32 is defined as const PCRE_UCHAR32 *In very many unsigned int is a bit data type When PCRE is it defines PCRE_UCHAR32 as unsigned but checks that it really is a bit data type If it is not
in these the offset passed back is the length of the pattern Note that the offset is in data not even in a UTF mode It may sometimes point into the middle of a UTF or UTF char acter If and the error codeptr argument is not a non zero error code number is returned via this argument in the event of an error This is in addition to the textual error message Error codes and messages are listed below If the final is NULL
all the files are read include the only direc tories that are processed are those that match one of the whether listed on the command obtained from file or by scanning a parent directory The pattern is a PCRE regular and is matched against the final component of the directory not the entire path The and x options do not apply to this pattern The option may be given any number of times If a directory matches both include dir and exclude it is excluded There is no short form for this option files without match Instead of outputting lines from the just output the names of the files that do not contain any lines that would have been output Each file name is output on a sepa rate line files with matches Instead of outputting lines from the just output the names of the files containing lines that would have been out put Each file name is output on a separate line Searching normally stops as soon as a matching line is found in a file if the matching continues in order to obtain the correct and those files that have at least one match are listed along with their counts Using this option with c is a way of sup pressing the listing of files with no matches standard input is used There is no short form for this option line buffered When this option is input is read and processed line by and the output is flushed after each write By input is read in large unless pcregrep can determine that it is reading from a its use will affect perfor and the show each match as a line number
PCRE AND BIT LIBRARIES As well as support for bit character PCRE also supports bit by means of two additional libraries They can be built as well or instead of
it does not apply to patterns specified by any of the include or exclude options ENVIRONMENT VARIABLES The environment variables LC_ALL and LC_CTYPE are in that for a locale The first one that is set is used This can be overridden by the locale option If no locale is the PCRE library s with what ever newline sequences they have in the input the setting of this option does not affect the interpretation of files specified by the exclude or include from which are assumed to use the operating system s standard newline nor does it affect the way in which pcregrep writes informational messages to the standard error and output streams For these it uses the string n to indicate relying on the C I O library to convert this to an appropriate sequence OPTIONS COMPATIBILITY Many of the short and long forms of pcregrep s options are the same as in the GNU grep program Any long option of the form xxx the file file include line offsets
The following names for option bits are defined in the pcre h header the pattern is forced to be that it is constrained to match only at the first matching point in the string that is being which is the only way to do it in Perl PCRE_AUTO_CALLOUT If this bit is all with before each pattern item For discussion of the callout see the pcrecallout documentation PCRE_BSR_ANYCRLF PCRE_BSR_UNICODE These or or to match any Unicode newline sequence The default is specified when PCRE is built It can be overridden from within the or by set ting an option when a compiled pattern is matched PCRE_CASELESS If this bit is letters in the pattern match both upper and lower case letters It is equivalent to Perl s i and it can be changed within a pattern by PCRE always understands the concept of case for characters whose values are less so caseless matching is always possible For characters with higher the concept of case is supported if PCRE is com piled with Unicode property but not otherwise If you want to use caseless matching for characters and you must ensure that PCRE is compiled with Unicode property support as well as with UTF support PCRE_DOLLAR_ENDONLY If this bit is a dollar metacharacter in the pattern matches only at the end of the subject string Without this a dollar also matches immediately before a newline at the end of the and no way to set it within a pattern PCRE_DOTALL If this bit is a dot metacharacter in the pattern matches a char acter of any including one that indicates a newline it only ever matches one even if newlines are coded as CRLF Without this a dot does not match when the current position is at a newline This option is equivalent to Perl s s option
it defaults to the value that is set for with match which imposes no additional constraints you can set a lower limit by for with match limit PCRE is built with a set of tables that are distributed in the file pcre_chartables c dist These tables are for ASCII codes only If you add enable rebuild chartables to the configure the distributed tables are no longer used a program called dftables is compiled and run This outputs the source for new set of created in the default locale of your C run time which is a superset of ASCII This is the case for most computer operating systems PCRE how be compiled to run in an EBCDIC environment by adding enable ebcdic to the configure command This setting implies enable rebuild charta bles You should only use it if you know that you are in an EBCDIC in some EBCDIC is used In such an environment you should use enable ebcdic nl25 as well or instead enable ebcdic The EBCDIC character for CR has the same value as in Whichever of and is not chosen as LF is made to correspond to the Unicode NEL char such as enable newline is and equivalent run time options
a negative value specifies a zero terminated string If byte_order is it is assumed that the string starts off in host byte order This may be changed by byte order a non zero value of the integer to which it points means that the input starts off in host byte order

a value of means that R matches only or CRLF The default can be overridden when a pat tern is compiled or matched PCRE_CONFIG_LINK_SIZE The output is an integer that contains the number of bytes used for internal linkage in compiled regular expressions For the bit the value can or For the bit the value is either or and is still a number of bytes For the bit the value is either or and is still a number of bytes The default value of is sufficient for all but the most massive patterns
a negative value specifies a zero terminated string If byte_order is it is assumed that the string starts off in host byte order This may be changed by byte order a non zero value of the integer to which it points means that the input starts off in host byte otherwise the opposite order is assumed BOMs in the string can change this The final byte order is passed back at the end of processing If keep_boms is not byte order mark including the zero terminator if the string was zero terminated SUBJECT STRING OFFSETS The lengths and starting offsets of subject strings must be specified in bit data and the offsets within subject strings that are returned by the matching functions are in also bit units rather than bytes NAMED SUBPATTERNS The name to number translation table that is maintained for named sub patterns uses bit characters The PCRE_UTF32 and which correspond to PCRE_UTF8 and PCRE_NO_UTF8_CHECK in the bit library In these new options define the same bits in the options word There is a discussion about the validity of UTF strings in the pcreunicode page For the otherwise If this option is given to or if the PCRE_CONFIG_UTF8 or PCRE_CONFIG_UTF16 option is given to pcre32_con the result is the PCRE_ERROR_BADOPTION error CHARACTER CODES In bit when PCRE_UTF32 is not character values are treated in the same way as in non UTF of that they can range from to instead of to Charac ter types for characters less than can therefore be influenced by the locale in the same way as before Characters greater than have only one and no the character code is in the range with the exception of values in the range xd800 to xdfff because those are surrogate values that are ill formed in UTF A UTF string can indicate its endianness by special code knows as a byte order expecting strings to be in host byte order A utility function called for if a pattern compiled with corresponding to the PCRE_UTF8_ERR codes for UTF strings that are described in the section entitled Reason codes for invalid UTF strings in the main pcreapi page The UTF errors the error text that is passed back by zero terminated CALLOUTS The subject and mark fields in the callout block that is passed to a callout function point to bit vectors TESTING The pcretest program continues to operate with bit input and output but it can be used for testing the bit library If it is run with the command line patterns and subject strings are con verted from bit to bit before being passed to PCRE

This file contains a concatenation of the PCRE man converted to plain text format for ease of searching with a text or for use on systems that do not have a man page processor The small individual files that give synopses of each function in the library have not been included Neither has the pcredemo program There are separate text files for the pcregrep and pcretest commands with library names and libpcre32 January saw the first release of a new known as PCRE2

a negative value specifies a zero terminated string If byte_order is it is assumed that the string starts off in host byte order This may be changed by byte order a non zero value of the integer to which it points means that the input starts off in host byte otherwise the opposite order is assumed BOMs in the string can change this The final byte order is passed back at the end of processing If keep_boms is not byte order mark including the zero terminator if the string was zero terminated SUBJECT STRING OFFSETS The lengths and starting offsets of subject strings must be specified in bit data and the offsets within subject strings that are returned by the matching functions are in also bit units rather than bytes NAMED SUBPATTERNS The name to number translation table that is maintained for named sub patterns uses bit characters The PCRE_UTF16 and PCRE_NO_UTF16_CHECK

this is a typedef for a structure whose contents are not externally defined It is up to the caller to free the that it does not depend on memory the complete pcre data block is not fully because it may contain a copy of the tableptr argu which is an those that are compatible with but some others as well can also be set and unset from within the the contents of the options argument specifies their settings at the start of compilation and execution The PCRE_NO_UTF8_CHECK
this overrides any other settings See the pcrepattern page for details of the special character sequences In the PCRE documentation the word newline is used to mean the char acter or pair of characters that indicate a line break The choice of newline convention affects the handling of the and dollar the handling of CRLF is a recognized line ending the match position advance ment for a non anchored pattern There is more detail about this in the section on nor does it affect what R which is controlled in a similar but by separate options MULTITHREADING The PCRE functions can be used in multi threading with the proviso that the memory management functions pointed to by and pcre_stack_free

THE PCRE BIT LIBRARY Starting with it is possible to compile a PCRE library that supports bit character including UTF as well as or instead of the original bit library This work was done by Christian Persch
this overrides any other settings See the pcrepattern page for details of the special character sequences In the PCRE documentation the word newline is used to mean the char acter or pair of characters that indicate a line break The choice of newline convention affects the handling of the and dollar the handling of CRLF is a recognized line ending the match position advance ment for a non anchored pattern There is more detail about this in the section on nor does it affect what R which is controlled in a similar but by separate options MULTITHREADING The PCRE functions can be used in multi threading with the proviso that the memory management functions pointed to by and and the callout and stack checking functions pointed to by pcre_callout and are shared by all threads The compiled form of a regular expression is not altered during match so the same compiled pattern can safely be used by several threads at once If the just in time optimization feature is being it needs sepa rate memory stack areas for each thread See the pcrejit documentation for more details SAVING PRECOMPILED PATTERNS FOR LATER USE The compiled form of a regular expression can be saved and re used at a later possibly by a different program
re
Initial value:
= pcre_compile(
"^A.*Z",
0,
&error,
&erroffset,
NULL)
pcre_compile
a negative value specifies a zero terminated string If byte_order is it is assumed that the string starts off in host byte order This may be changed by byte order a non zero value of the integer to which it points means that the input starts off in host byte otherwise the opposite order is assumed BOMs in the string can change this The final byte order is passed back at the end of processing If keep_boms is not byte order mark including the zero terminator if the string was zero terminated SUBJECT STRING OFFSETS The lengths and starting offsets of subject strings must be specified in bit data and the offsets within subject strings that are returned by the matching functions are in also bit units rather than bytes NAMED SUBPATTERNS The name to number translation table that is maintained for named sub patterns uses bit characters The PCRE_UTF16 and which correspond to PCRE_UTF8 and PCRE_NO_UTF8_CHECK in the bit library In these new options define the same bits in the options word There is a discussion about the validity of UTF strings in the pcreunicode page For the otherwise If this option is given to or if the PCRE_CONFIG_UTF8 or PCRE_CONFIG_UTF32 option is given to pcre16_con the result is the PCRE_ERROR_BADOPTION error CHARACTER CODES In bit when PCRE_UTF16 is not character values are treated in the same way as in non UTF of that they can range from to instead of to Character types for characters less than can therefore be influenced by the locale in the same way as before Characters greater than have only one and no the character code is in the range with the exception of values in the range xd800 to xdfff because those are surrogate values that are used in pairs to encode values greater than xffff A UTF string can indicate its endianness by special code knows as a byte order expecting strings to be in host byte order A utility function called for if a pattern compiled with pcre_compile() is passed to pcre16_exec().There are new error codes whose names begin with PCRE_UTF16_ERR for invalid UTF-16 strings
error
const char * error

it defaults to the value that is set for with match which imposes no additional constraints you can set a lower limit by for with match limit recursion
Initial value:
=10000
to the configure command. This value can also be overridden at run
time.
CREATING CHARACTER TABLES AT BUILD TIME
PCRE uses fixed tables for processing characters whose code values are
less than 256. By default
be
a value of means that R matches only or CRLF The default can be overridden when a pat tern is compiled or matched PCRE_CONFIG_LINK_SIZE The output is an integer that contains the number of bytes used for internal linkage in compiled regular expressions For the bit the value can be
Definition: pcre.txt:1971
tables
it defaults to the value that is set for with match which imposes no additional constraints you can set a lower limit by for with match limit PCRE is built with a set of tables that are distributed in the file pcre_chartables c dist These tables are for ASCII codes only If you add enable rebuild chartables to the configure the distributed tables are no longer used a program called dftables is compiled and run This outputs the source for new set of tables

in these the offset passed back is the length of the pattern Note that the offset is in data not characters

configure
it is run only when the default link size of is and the thirteenth test is run only when JIT support is not available They test some JIT specific features such as information output from pcretest about JIT compilation The and sixteenth tests are run only in bit and the and nineteenth tests are run only in bit mode These are tests that generate different output in the two modes They are for general UTF and Unicode property respectively The twentieth test is run only in bit mode It tests some specific bit features of the DFA matching engine The twenty first and twenty second tests are run only in bit when the link size is set to for the bit library They test reloading pre compiled patterns The twenty third and twenty fourth tests are run only in bit mode They are for general and UTF respectively The twenty fifth and twenty sixth tests are run only in bit mode They are for general and UTF respectively Character tables For PCRE uses four tables for manipulating and identifying characters whose code point values are less than The final argument of the a set of default tables that is built into the binary is used The source file called pcre_chartables c contains the default set of tables By this is created as a copy of pcre_chartables c which contains tables for ASCII coding if enable rebuild chartables is specified for configure
