Definition: pcre.txt:447
values
The following names for option bits are defined in the pcre h header the pattern is forced to be that it is constrained to match only at the first matching point in the string that is being which is the only way to do it in Perl PCRE_AUTO_CALLOUT If this bit is all with before each pattern item For discussion of the callout see the pcrecallout documentation PCRE_BSR_ANYCRLF PCRE_BSR_UNICODE These or or to match any Unicode newline sequence The default is specified when PCRE is built It can be overridden from within the or by set ting an option when a compiled pattern is matched PCRE_CASELESS If this bit is letters in the pattern match both upper and lower case letters It is equivalent to Perl s i and it can be changed within a pattern by PCRE always understands the concept of case for characters whose values are less so caseless matching is always possible For characters with higher values
Definition: pcre.txt:2144
value
The following names for option bits are defined in the pcre h header the pattern is forced to be that it is constrained to match only at the first matching point in the string that is being which is the only way to do it in Perl PCRE_AUTO_CALLOUT If this bit is all with before each pattern item For discussion of the callout see the pcrecallout documentation PCRE_BSR_ANYCRLF PCRE_BSR_UNICODE These or or to match any Unicode newline sequence The default is specified when PCRE is built It can be overridden from within the or by set ting an option when a compiled pattern is matched PCRE_CASELESS If this bit is letters in the pattern match both upper and lower case letters It is equivalent to Perl s i and it can be changed within a pattern by PCRE always understands the concept of case for characters whose values are less so caseless matching is always possible For characters with higher the concept of case is supported if PCRE is com piled with Unicode property but not otherwise If you want to use caseless matching for characters and you must ensure that PCRE is compiled with Unicode property support as well as with UTF support PCRE_DOLLAR_ENDONLY If this bit is a dollar metacharacter in the pattern matches only at the end of the subject string Without this a dollar also matches immediately before a newline at the end of the and no way to set it within a pattern PCRE_DOTALL If this bit is a dot metacharacter in the pattern matches a char acter of any value
Definition: pcre.txt:2162
run
in other force each pattern to be studied If s is all the JIT compile options are passed to pcre[16|32] causing just in time optimization to be set up if it is for both full and partial matching Specific JIT compile options can be selected by following s with a digit in the range which selects the JIT compile modes as the either specifying no studying at or suppressing JIT com pilation If the I or D option is present on a information about the result of studying is not included when studying is caused only by s and neither i nor d is present on the command line This behaviour means that the output from tests that are run with and without s should be except when options that output information about the actual running of a match are set The and tm which give information about resources are likely to produce different output with and without s Output may also differ if the C option is present on an individual pattern This uses callouts to trace the the matching and this may be different between studied and non studied patterns If the pattern contains MARK items there may also be for the same reason The s command line option can be overridden for spe cific patterns that should never be and match many times with a and output the resulting times per or because you will then get the size output a zillion and the timing will be distorted You can control the number of iterations that are used for timing by following t with a t iter ates times The default is to iterate times tm This is like t except that it times only the matching not the compile or study phases T TM These behave like t and but in at the end of a run

PCRE
a negative value specifies a zero terminated string If byte_order is it is assumed that the string starts off in host byte order This may be changed by byte order a non zero value of the integer to which it points means that the input starts off in host byte otherwise the opposite order is assumed BOMs in the string can change this The final byte order is passed back at the end of processing If keep_boms is not byte order mark including the zero terminator if the string was zero terminated SUBJECT STRING OFFSETS The lengths and starting offsets of subject strings must be specified in bit data and the offsets within subject strings that are returned by the matching functions are in also bit units rather than bytes NAMED SUBPATTERNS The name to number translation table that is instead of to Character types for characters less than can therefore be influenced by the locale in the same way as before Characters greater than have only one and no the character code is in the range with the exception of values in the range xd800 to xdfff because those are surrogate values that are used in pairs to encode values greater than xffff A UTF string can indicate its endianness by special code knows as a byte order expecting strings to be in host byte order A utility function called for if a pattern compiled with corresponding to the PCRE_UTF8_ERR codes for UTF strings that are described in the section entitled Reason codes for invalid UTF strings in the main pcreapi page The UTF errors the error text that is passed back by zero terminated CALLOUTS The subject and mark fields in the callout block that is passed to a callout function point to bit vectors TESTING The pcretest program continues to operate with bit input and output but it can be used for testing the bit library If it is run with the command line patterns and subject strings are con verted from bit to bit before being passed to PCRE

code
if JIT support is being successfully it is not relevant it does not apply to which does not use deeply nested recursion There is a discussion about stack sizes in the pcrestack man page For PCRE uses four tables for manipulating and identifying characters whose code point values are less than By it uses a set of tables for ASCII encoding that is part of the distribution If you specify enable rebuild chartables a program called dftables is compiled and run in the default C locale when you obey make It builds a source file called pcre_chartables c If you do not specify this pcre_chartables c is created as a copy of pcre_chartables c dist See Character tables below for further information It is possible to compile PCRE for use on systems that use EBCDIC as their character code(as opposed to ASCII/Unicode) by specifying--enable-ebcdic This automatically implies--enable-rebuild-chartables(see above).However

THE PCRE BIT LIBRARY Starting with release
this is a typedef for a structure whose contents are not externally defined It is up to the caller to free the that it does not depend on memory the complete pcre data block is not fully relocatable
Either of the functions via which a numerical error code can be returned To avoid too much repetition
The function specifying which information is required
it defaults to the value that is set for with match which imposes no additional constraints you can set a lower limit by for with match limit PCRE is built with a set of tables that are distributed in the file pcre_chartables c dist These tables are for ASCII codes only If you add enable rebuild chartables to the configure the distributed tables are no longer used a program called dftables is compiled and run This outputs the source for new set of created in the default locale of your C run time which is a superset of ASCII This is the case for most computer operating systems PCRE how be compiled to run in an EBCDIC environment by adding enable ebcdic to the configure command This setting implies enable rebuild charta bles You should only use it if you know that you are in an EBCDIC in some EBCDIC is used In such an environment you should use enable ebcdic nl25 as well or instead enable ebcdic The EBCDIC character for CR has the same value as in Whichever of and is not chosen as LF is made to correspond to the Unicode NEL char such as enable newline is and equivalent run time refer to these character values in an EBCDIC environment PCREGREP OPTIONS FOR COMPRESSED FILE SUPPORT By pcregrep reads all files as plain text You can build it so that it recognizes files whose names end in gz or and reads them with libz or respectively
they just use different data types for their arguments and results
instead output the number of lines that would other wise have been shown If no lines are the number zero is output If several files are are being scanned
it defaults to the value that is set for with match which imposes no additional constraints you can set a lower limit by for with match limit PCRE is built with a set of tables that are distributed in the file pcre_chartables c dist These tables are for ASCII codes only If you add enable rebuild chartables to the configure the distributed tables are no longer used a program called dftables is compiled and run This outputs the source for new set of created in the default locale of your C run time which is a superset of ASCII This is the case for most computer operating systems PCRE how be compiled to run in an EBCDIC environment by adding enable ebcdic to the configure command This setting implies enable rebuild charta bles You should only use it if you know that you are in an EBCDIC in some EBCDIC is used In such an environment you should use enable ebcdic nl25 as well or instead enable ebcdic The EBCDIC character for CR has the same value as in Whichever of and is not chosen as LF is made to correspond to the Unicode NEL char such as enable newline is and equivalent run time refer to these character values in an EBCDIC environment PCREGREP OPTIONS FOR COMPRESSED FILE SUPPORT By pcregrep reads all files as plain text You can build it so that it recognizes files whose names end in gz or and reads them with libz or by adding one or both of enable pcregrep libz enable pcregrep libbz2 to the configure command These options naturally require that the rel evant libraries are installed on your system Configuration will fail if they are not PCREGREP BUFFER SIZE pcregrep uses an internal buffer to hold a window on the file it is scanning
information about the compiled pattern is given after compilation M Behave as if each data line contains the M escape sequence
see also the pcrepattern documentation PCRE_EXTENDED If this bit is set
it is not the default The Unicode tables correspond to Unicode release In addition to the Perl compatible matching PCRE contains an alternative function that matches the same compiled patterns in a dif ferent way In certain the alternative function has some advantages For a discussion of the two matching see the pcrematching page PCRE is written in C and released as a C library A number of people have written wrappers and interfaces of various kinds In Google Inc have provided a comprehensive C wrapper for the bit library This is now included as part of the PCRE distribution The pcrecpp page has details of this interface Other people s contribu tions can be found in the Contrib directory at the primary FTP site
they operate in a different and are not Perl compatible This alternative has advan tages and disadvantages compared with the standard and these are described below When there is only one possible way in which a given subject string can match a the two algorithms give the same answer A difference when there are multiple possibilities For if the pattern<.*> is matched against the string<something><something else><something further> there are three possible answers The standard algorithm finds only one of whereas the alternative algorithm finds all three REGULAR EXPRESSIONS AS TREES The set of strings that are matched by a regular expression can be rep resented as a tree structure An unlimited repetition in the pattern makes the tree of infinite size

=3
to the configure command. The value given must be 2
be
a value of means that R matches only or CRLF The default can be overridden when a pat tern is compiled or matched PCRE_CONFIG_LINK_SIZE The output is an integer that contains the number of bytes used for internal linkage in compiled regular expressions For the bit the value can be

Definition: pcre.txt:2162
given
all the files are read include the only direc tories that are processed are those that match one of the whether listed on the command obtained from file or by scanning a parent directory The pattern is a PCRE regular and is matched against the final component of the directory not the entire path The and x options do not apply to this pattern The option may be given any number of times If a directory matches both include dir and exclude it is excluded There is no short form for this option files without match Instead of outputting lines from the just output the names of the files that do not contain any lines that would have been output Each file name is output on a sepa rate line files with matches Instead of outputting lines from the just output the names of the files containing lines that would have been out put Each file name is output on a separate line Searching normally stops as soon as a matching line is found in a file if the matching continues in order to obtain the correct and those files that have at least one match are listed along with their counts Using this option with c is a way of sup pressing the listing of files with no matches standard input is used There is no short form for this option line buffered When this option is given
Definition: pcregrep.txt:409
PCRE AND BIT LIBRARIES As well as support for bit character strings
the second argument is a pointer to a variable into which the information is placed The returned value is zero on success
The following names for option bits are defined in the pcre h header the pattern is forced to be that it is constrained to match only at the first matching point in the string that is being which is the only way to do it in Perl PCRE_AUTO_CALLOUT If this bit is all with before each pattern item For discussion of the callout see the pcrecallout documentation PCRE_BSR_ANYCRLF PCRE_BSR_UNICODE These or or to match any Unicode newline sequence The default is specified when PCRE is built It can be overridden from within the or by set ting an option when a compiled pattern is matched PCRE_CASELESS If this bit is letters in the pattern match both upper and lower case letters It is equivalent to Perl s i and it can be changed within a pattern by PCRE always understands the concept of case for characters whose values are less so caseless matching is always possible For characters with higher the concept of case is supported if PCRE is com piled with Unicode property support
THE PCRE BIT LIBRARY Starting with it is possible to compile a PCRE library that supports bit character including UTF as well as or instead of the original bit library This work was done by Christian based on the work done by Zoltan Herczeg for the bit library All three libraries contain identical sets of func used in exactly the same way Only the names of the functions and the data types of their arguments and results are different To avoid over complication and reduce the documentation maintenance most of the PCRE documentation describes the bit with only occasional references to the bit and bit libraries This page describes what is different when you use the bit library but you must take care when processing any particular pattern to use functions from just one library For if you want to study a pattern that was compiled with you must do so with not and you must free the study data with pcre h It contains prototypes for all the functions in all as well as definitions of struc error etc THE LIBRARY NAME In Unix like systems
in these the offset passed back is the length of the pattern Note that the offset is in data not even in a UTF mode It may sometimes point into the middle of a UTF or UTF char acter If and the error codeptr argument is not a non zero error code number is returned via this argument in the event of an error This is in addition to the textual error message Error codes and messages are listed below If the final tableptr
it defaults to the value that is set for with match which imposes no additional constraints you can set a lower limit by for with match limit PCRE is built with a set of tables that are distributed in the file pcre_chartables c dist These tables are for ASCII codes only If you add enable rebuild chartables to the configure the distributed tables are no longer used a program called dftables is compiled and run This outputs the source for new set of tables
it defaults to the value that is set for with match which imposes no additional constraints you can set a lower limit by for with match limit PCRE is built with a set of tables that are distributed in the file pcre_chartables c dist These tables are for ASCII codes only If you add enable rebuild chartables to the configure the distributed tables are no longer used a program called dftables is compiled and run This outputs the source for new set of created in the default locale of your C run time which is a superset of ASCII This is the case for most computer operating systems PCRE how be compiled to run in an EBCDIC environment by adding enable ebcdic to the configure command This setting implies enable rebuild charta bles You should only use it if you know that you are in an EBCDIC in some EBCDIC is used In such an environment you should use enable ebcdic nl25 as well or instead enable ebcdic The EBCDIC character for CR has the same value as in Whichever of and is not chosen as LF is made to correspond to the Unicode NEL char such as enable newline is and equivalent run time refer to these character values in an EBCDIC environment PCREGREP OPTIONS FOR COMPRESSED FILE SUPPORT By pcregrep reads all files as plain text You can build it so that it recognizes files whose names end in gz or and reads them with libz or by adding one or both of enable pcregrep libz enable pcregrep libbz2 to the configure command These options naturally require that the rel evant libraries are installed on your system Configuration will fail if they are not PCREGREP BUFFER SIZE pcregrep uses an internal buffer to hold a window on the file it is in order to be able to output before and after lines when it finds a match The size of the buffer is controlled by a parameter whose default value is The buffer itself is three times this but because of the way it is used for holding before the long est line that is guaranteed to be processable is the parameter size You can change the default parameter value by for with pcregrep override this value by specifying a run time option PCRETEST OPTION FOR LIBREADLINE SUPPORT If you add enable pcretest libreadline to the configure pcretest is linked with the libreadline and when its input is from a terminal

they operate in a different and are not Perl compatible This alternative has advan tages and disadvantages compared with the standard and these are described below When there is only one possible way in which a given subject string can match a the two algorithms give the same answer A difference when there are multiple possibilities For if the pattern<.*> is matched against the string<something><something else><something further> there are three possible answers The standard algorithm finds only one of them

HANDLING VERY LARGE PATTERNS
Within a compiled pattern
configure
it is run only when the default link size of is and the thirteenth test is run only when JIT support is not available They test some JIT specific features such as information output from pcretest about JIT compilation The and sixteenth tests are run only in bit and the and nineteenth tests are run only in bit mode These are tests that generate different output in the two modes They are for general UTF and Unicode property respectively The twentieth test is run only in bit mode It tests some specific bit features of the DFA matching engine The twenty first and twenty second tests are run only in bit when the link size is set to for the bit library They test reloading pre compiled patterns The twenty third and twenty fourth tests are run only in bit mode They are for general and UTF respectively The twenty fifth and twenty sixth tests are run only in bit mode They are for general and UTF respectively Character tables For PCRE uses four tables for manipulating and identifying characters whose code point values are less than The final argument of the a set of default tables that is built into the binary is used The source file called pcre_chartables c contains the default set of tables By this is created as a copy of pcre_chartables c which contains tables for ASCII coding if enable rebuild chartables is specified for configure

Definition: pcre.txt:1159
to
a negative value specifies a zero terminated string If byte_order is it is assumed that the string starts off in host byte order This may be changed by byte order a non zero value of the integer to which it points means that the input starts off in host byte otherwise the opposite order is assumed BOMs in the string can change this The final byte order is passed back at the end of processing If keep_boms is not byte order mark including the zero terminator if the string was zero terminated SUBJECT STRING OFFSETS The lengths and starting offsets of subject strings must be specified in bit data and the offsets within subject strings that are returned by the matching functions are in also bit units rather than bytes NAMED SUBPATTERNS The name to number translation table that is maintained for named sub patterns uses bit characters The PCRE_UTF16 and which correspond to PCRE_UTF8 and PCRE_NO_UTF8_CHECK in the bit library In these new options define the same bits in the options word There is a discussion about the validity of UTF strings in the pcreunicode page For the otherwise If this option is given to or if the PCRE_CONFIG_UTF8 or PCRE_CONFIG_UTF32 option is given to pcre16_con the result is the PCRE_ERROR_BADOPTION error CHARACTER CODES In bit when PCRE_UTF16 is not character values are treated in the same way as in non UTF of that they can range from to instead of to Character types for characters less than can therefore be influenced by the locale in the same way as before Characters greater than have only one and no the character code is in the range to
Definition: pcre.txt:447
compiled
a negative value specifies a zero terminated string If byte_order is it is assumed that the string starts off in host byte order This may be changed by byte order a non zero value of the integer to which it points means that the input starts off in host byte otherwise the opposite order is assumed BOMs in the string can change this The final byte order is passed back at the end of processing If keep_boms is not byte order mark including the zero terminator if the string was zero terminated SUBJECT STRING OFFSETS The lengths and starting offsets of subject strings must be specified in bit data and the offsets within subject strings that are returned by the matching functions are in also bit units rather than bytes NAMED SUBPATTERNS The name to number translation table that is maintained for named sub patterns uses bit characters The PCRE_UTF16 and which correspond to PCRE_UTF8 and PCRE_NO_UTF8_CHECK in the bit library In these new options define the same bits in the options word There is a discussion about the validity of UTF strings in the pcreunicode page For the otherwise If this option is given to or if the PCRE_CONFIG_UTF8 or PCRE_CONFIG_UTF32 option is given to pcre16_con the result is the PCRE_ERROR_BADOPTION error CHARACTER CODES In bit when PCRE_UTF16 is not character values are treated in the same way as in non UTF of that they can range from to instead of to Character types for characters less than can therefore be influenced by the locale in the same way as before Characters greater than have only one and no the character code is in the range with the exception of values in the range xd800 to xdfff because those are surrogate values that are used in pairs to encode values greater than xffff A UTF string can indicate its endianness by special code knows as a byte order expecting strings to be in host byte order A utility function called for if a pattern compiled with corresponding to the PCRE_UTF8_ERR codes for UTF strings that are described in the section entitled Reason codes for invalid UTF strings in the main pcreapi page The UTF errors the error text that is passed back by zero terminated CALLOUTS The subject and mark fields in the callout block that is passed to a callout function point to bit vectors TESTING The pcretest program continues to operate with bit input and output but it can be used for testing the bit library If it is run with the command line patterns and subject strings are con verted from bit to bit before being passed to and the bit library functions are used instead of the bit ones Returned bit strings are converted to bit for output If both the bit and the bit libraries were not compiled

a
The following names for option bits are defined in the pcre h header the pattern is forced to be that it is constrained to match only at the first matching point in the string that is being which is the only way to do it in Perl PCRE_AUTO_CALLOUT If this bit is all with before each pattern item For discussion of the callout see the pcrecallout documentation PCRE_BSR_ANYCRLF PCRE_BSR_UNICODE These or or to match any Unicode newline sequence The default is specified when PCRE is built It can be overridden from within the or by set ting an option when a compiled pattern is matched PCRE_CASELESS If this bit is letters in the pattern match both upper and lower case letters It is equivalent to Perl s i and it can be changed within a pattern by a(?i) option setting.In UTF-8 mode
pattern

Definition: pcre.txt:1381
this overrides any other settings See the pcrepattern page for details of the special character sequences In the PCRE documentation the word newline is used to mean the char acter or pair of characters that indicate a line break The choice of newline convention affects the handling of the and dollar the handling of CRLF is a recognized line ending the match position advance ment for a non anchored pattern There is more detail about this in the section on nor does it affect what R which is controlled in a similar but by separate options MULTITHREADING The PCRE functions can be used in multi threading with the proviso that the memory management functions pointed to by and and the callout and stack checking functions pointed to by pcre_callout and are shared by all threads The compiled form of a regular expression is not altered during match so the same compiled pattern can safely be used by several threads at once If the just in time optimization feature is being it needs sepa rate memory stack areas for each thread See the pcrejit documentation for more details SAVING PRECOMPILED PATTERNS FOR LATER USE The compiled form of a regular expression can be saved and re used at a later time
THE PCRE BIT LIBRARY Starting with it is possible to compile a PCRE library that supports bit character including UTF as well as or instead of the original bit library This work was done by Christian based on the work done by Zoltan Herczeg for the bit library All three libraries contain identical sets of func tions
a negative value specifies a zero terminated string If byte_order is it is assumed that the string starts off in host byte order This may be changed by byte order a non zero value of the integer to which it points means that the input starts off in host byte otherwise the opposite order is assumed BOMs in the string can change this The final byte order is passed back at the end of processing If keep_boms is not byte order mark including the zero terminator if the string was zero terminated SUBJECT STRING OFFSETS The lengths and starting offsets of subject strings must be specified in bit data and the offsets within subject strings that are returned by the matching functions are in also bit units rather than bytes NAMED SUBPATTERNS The name to number translation table that is maintained for named sub patterns uses bit characters The PCRE_UTF32 and which correspond to PCRE_UTF8 and PCRE_NO_UTF8_CHECK in the bit library In these new options define the same bits in the options word There is a discussion about the validity of UTF strings in the pcreunicode page For the otherwise If this option is given to or if the PCRE_CONFIG_UTF8 or PCRE_CONFIG_UTF16 option is given to pcre32_con the result is the PCRE_ERROR_BADOPTION error CHARACTER CODES In bit when PCRE_UTF32 is not character values are treated in the same way as in non UTF of that they can range from to instead of to Charac ter types for characters less than can therefore be influenced by the locale in the same way as before Characters greater than have only one and no the character code is in the range to

THE PCRE BIT LIBRARY Starting with it is possible to compile a PCRE library that supports bit character including UTF as well as or instead of the original bit library This work was done by Christian based on the work done by Zoltan Herczeg for the bit library All three libraries contain identical sets of func used in exactly the same way Only the names of the functions and the data types of their arguments and results are different To avoid over complication and reduce the documentation maintenance most of the PCRE documentation describes the bit with only occasional references to the bit and bit libraries This page describes what is different when you use the bit library but you must take care when processing any particular pattern to use functions from just one library For if you want to study a pattern that was compiled with you must do so with not and you must free the study data with pcre h It contains prototypes for all the functions in all as well as definitions of struc error etc THE LIBRARY NAME In Unix like the bit library is called and can normally be accesss by adding lpcre32 to the command for linking an application that uses PCRE STRING TYPES In the bit strings are passed to PCRE library functions as vectors of bytes with the C type char* In the bit strings are passed as vectors of unsigned bit quantities The macro PCRE_UCHAR32 specifies an appropriate data type
a negative value specifies a zero terminated string If byte_order is it is assumed that the string starts off in host byte order This may be changed by byte order a non zero value of the integer to which it points means that the input starts off in host byte otherwise the opposite order is assumed BOMs in the string can change this The final byte order is passed back at the end of processing If keep_boms is not byte order mark including the zero terminator if the string was zero terminated SUBJECT STRING OFFSETS The lengths and starting offsets of subject strings must be specified in bit data and the offsets within subject strings that are returned by the matching functions are in also bit units rather than bytes NAMED SUBPATTERNS The name to number translation table that is maintained for named sub patterns uses bit characters The PCRE_UTF32 and which correspond to PCRE_UTF8 and PCRE_NO_UTF8_CHECK in the bit library In these new options define the same bits in the options word There is a discussion about the validity of UTF strings in the pcreunicode page For the otherwise If this option is given to or if the PCRE_CONFIG_UTF8 or PCRE_CONFIG_UTF16 option is given to pcre32_con the result is the PCRE_ERROR_BADOPTION error CHARACTER CODES In bit when PCRE_UTF32 is not character values are treated in the same way as in non UTF of that they can range from to instead of to Charac ter types for characters less than can therefore be influenced by the locale in the same way as before Characters greater than have only one and no the character code is Unicode
in these the offset passed back is the length of the pattern Note that the offset is in data units

instead of to Charac ter types for characters less than can therefore be influenced by the locale in the same way as before Characters greater than have only one and no the character code is in the range with the exception of values in the range xd800 to xdfff because those are surrogate values that are ill formed in UTF A UTF string can indicate its endianness by special code knows as a byte order expecting strings to be in host byte order A utility function called for if a pattern compiled with corresponding to the PCRE_UTF8_ERR codes for UTF strings that are described in the section entitled Reason codes for invalid UTF strings in the main pcreapi page The UTF errors the error text that is passed back by zero terminated CALLOUTS The subject and mark fields in the callout block that is passed to a callout function point to bit vectors TESTING The pcretest program continues to operate with bit input and output but it can be used for testing the bit library If it is run with the command line patterns and subject strings are con verted from bit to bit before being passed to and the bit library functions are used instead of the bit ones Returned bit strings are converted to bit for output If both the bit and the bit libraries were not pcretest defaults to bit and the option is ignored When PCRE is being the RunTest script that is called by make check uses the pcretest C option to discover which of the bit and bit libraries has been and runs the tests appro priately NOT SUPPORTED IN BIT MODE Not all the features of the bit library are available with the bit library The C and POSIX wrapper functions support only the bit and the pcregrep program is at present bit only AUTHOR Philip Hazel University Computing Service Cambridge England REVISION Last updated
the default is This limit does not take into account the stack that may already be used by the calling applica tion For finer control over compilation stack usage
this overrides any other settings See the pcrepattern page for details of the special character sequences In the PCRE documentation the word newline is used to mean the char acter or pair of characters that indicate a line break The choice of newline convention affects the handling of the and dollar the handling of CRLF is a recognized line ending the match position advance ment for a non anchored pattern There is more detail about this in the section on nor does it affect what R which is controlled in a similar but by separate options MULTITHREADING The PCRE functions can be used in multi threading with the proviso that the memory management functions pointed to by and and the callout and stack checking functions pointed to by pcre_callout and are shared by all threads The compiled form of a regular expression is not altered during match so the same compiled pattern can safely be used by several threads at once If the just in time optimization feature is being used
they just use different data types for their arguments and and their names start with pcre16_ or pcre32_ instead of pcre_ For every option that has UTF8 in its there are corresponding bit and bit names with UTF8 replaced by UTF16 or UTF32
The following names for option bits are defined in the pcre h header the pattern is forced to be that it is constrained to match only at the first matching point in the string that is being which is the only way to do it in Perl PCRE_AUTO_CALLOUT If this bit is all with before each pattern item For discussion of the callout see the pcrecallout documentation PCRE_BSR_ANYCRLF PCRE_BSR_UNICODE These or or to match any Unicode newline sequence The default is specified when PCRE is built It can be overridden from within the or by set ting an option when a compiled pattern is matched PCRE_CASELESS If this bit is letters in the pattern match both upper and lower case letters It is equivalent to Perl s i and it can be changed within a pattern by PCRE always understands the concept of case for characters whose values are less so caseless matching is always possible For characters with higher the concept of case is supported if PCRE is com piled with Unicode property but not otherwise If you want to use caseless matching for characters and you must ensure that PCRE is compiled with Unicode property support as well as with UTF support PCRE_DOLLAR_ENDONLY If this bit is a dollar metacharacter in the pattern matches only at the end of the subject string Without this a dollar also matches immediately before a newline at the end of the and no way to set it within a pattern PCRE_DOTALL If this bit is a dot metacharacter in the pattern matches a char acter of any value
